text: Backlog, ocena przepisana z untappd, w ramach uzupełniania profilu na ratebeer. Wysokie wysycenie, bardzo palone, popielniczkowe. Nieprzyjemne.

This Irish Dry Stout is quite rich, black, and full bodied for the style, but it suits this beer nicely. Opaque body. Cocoa, coffee, and toasted grain smell flavor. Silky smooth feel. It was the perfect way for me to get in touch with my nonexistent Irish heritage.

Bottle from Boise Co-op. Dark brown / black pour with medium fluffy beige head. Aroma is tight in the wheel house for a stout, roast grains and burnt toast. Taste continues, but true to the style, it dries out in the finish.

(Listed as being only 5% ABV)rich deep dark brownish black hue with a thin beige cap. Rich chocolaty and leafy roasted black malt aroma thats all at once Irish and chocolaty sweet. Brilliant dry but chocolaty flavor thats a touch roasty and chocolate cake-ish. Really neat and clean, dessert flavored without being overly sweet.

Bottle 65cl
@ Cervezas Diferentes, Coslada, Spain.
A: Black.
T: Roasted malt, sweet, chocolate, coffee.
On tap at St. Augustine?s. Very dark brown, almost black, brown head. Aroma is coffee, roasted malt. Taste roasted burnt malt, slightly sweet and hoppy. Burnt malt aftertaste. Dry. Good.
Draft: Poured a pitch black with a tan head. Aroma is sweet and roasted malt mix. Taste was chocolate and roasted malt, smooth silky dry finish.

Pours jet black, with a nice crema head. Aroma is of roasted barley, espresso, licorice, and smoke. Tastes of roasted barley, dark chocolate, leather and smoke. Has a dry, full body mouthfeel with average carbonation. Very rich root beer quality to it.

UPDATED: APR 9, 2016 Draft at The Irish Pol. Opaque black pour with tan foam that reduced quickly but kept a lasting presence. Medium-bodied. Dark chocolate. Carob bean. Cold coffee. Liquorice. Celery root. Hints of dark stone fruit and berries. Fainter hints of smoke. Warms badly; becomes more glossy and less dry. Would likely be better on nitro.
Tight, creamy head thanks to a nitro tap. Roasty and chocolaty and suitably dry.
Bottle from Crafty Bottle, Lincoln. Deep black colour with a thin tan head. Aroma is citrus, roasted malt, and a touch of spice and berry. Taste sweet with a fruity sharpness.
On tap black with rich dense creamy nitro beige head. Mostly chocolate and whoppers in the aroma. More of a clean dry dark roast in the flavor. Very tasty dry stout.

650ml bottle. Pours an opaque black with a large, frothy, short lived, tan head that leaves spotty lacing. Sweet aroma of dark chocolate, roasted malt, coffee, and a hint of vanilla. Sweet flavour of roasted malt, dark chocolate, coffee and ash with a dry, bitter, slightly acidic finish. Light to medium body with an oily texture and soft carbonation. A solid dry stout.

Draft at the brewery, served in a flight. Pours a deep, nearly opaque coffee brown with a finger of tan head that settles into some lace in the glass and a lasting film atop the beer. Notes of cocoa, fudge, coffee, toast, and earth. Light-bodied, with moderate to medium carbonation and a smooth, toasty mouthfeel. Really nice take on the style. Straightforward but fulfilling.

[2/1/16] Draught at Moylans Brewery in Novato. Black with a creamy tan head. Aroma of chocolate, cream, roast. Sweet flavor, roasty, kinda milky, with some chocolate, coffee, and a bitterish finish. Medium-bodied.
Draft - Nitro - Roast and a touch of dark chocolate. Jet brown with a rich light brown head. Roast and cocoa with a dry finish.

On tap at Blackback Pub, Waterbury VT. 
This was poured into a becher pint glass. 
The appearance was a dark brown close to black color with a two finger white to off white foamy head that dissipated at a nice pace leaving some light stringy foamy lacing. 
The smell had a nice rich roasty smooth coffee aroma bursting over a delicate amount of chocolate underneath. Light bitter roots of black licorice slide in further underneath.
The taste was moderately bitter with the roasty portion backing it all up nicely. Light roasty to sweet aftertaste and a dry roasty finish. 
On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a fairly decent sessionability about it. Carbonation runs fairly light. Bitter and roasty feels stroll across my tongue. 
Overall, this was a pretty good Irish Dry stout. Id have again.

Draught at Moylans. Opaque black liquid with medium, solid tan head. Aroma of coffee, light licorice, light ash, fresh hops and toast. Taste is very light sweet and light bitter with notes of light licorice, coffee and light ash. Medium bodied with medium carbonation. Solid, true to style.

Draft at the brewpub. Dark brown reddy coloured pour with no head. Aroma is raisin, malt loaf, nutty malts, dried figs. Flavour is composed of dry malt bread, vanilla, woody. Dried fruits, raisin and figs. Palate is dry, semi sweet, powdery carbonation. I quite like it.

Draft at source. Nitro. Moderate coffee and chocolate aroma that is very inviting. Black with a very faint reddish highlight. Medium sized tan head. Taste is very chocolate forward with a creamy mouthfeel. Not overly bitter or roasty, very creamy and sweet. Enjoyable.

Backlog. Bottle at Cardinal 24.10.14. Black. Pale brown head quickly diminishing to almost nothing. Aroma of coffee, dark chocolate and roasted barley. Similar taste. Fine, but short, aftertaste. Thin and watery mouthfeel. High drinkability, though.

Sample on tap at the brewpub. Opaque black pour with creamy tan head. Aroma is roasty, burnt grain, light chocolate. Taste is roasty, nice chocolate, light ash. Palate is light, very dry. Nice dry stout.

Marrom escura, espuma bege de média formação e pouca persistência. Aroma de chocolate amargo, torrado, médio dulçor, maltada. Paladar trás um leve defumado e dulçor, amargor de grãos torrados. Corpo médio, baixa carbonatação. Aftertaste característico maltado, leve café, final seco como era de se prever. Boa !
On tap at Ølbaren, Copenhagen. Pours dark brown with small beige head. Aroma of roasted malt, dark fruits. Taste sweet and slightly fruity-sour.

Botella 66 cl tomada en el momento en el Lupulo 12..10..2015 (r482). Rey irían stout suave con sabores y aromas tostados suaves tirando a ciertos caramelos tostados. Amargo final escaso. Cuerpo ligero a medio muy fácil de beber. 5 vol. Normal.

650ml bottle from Appellation Wines. Pours opaque dark brown with a thin tan head. Aromas of dark chocolate, tar, leather. Taste is more dark chocolate and leather, liquorice. Slightly thin maybe but theres a good richness for the strength.

Bottle from Appellation Wines. 
Appearance - opaque black with a decent fawn head. 
Nose - creamy milk chocolate plus a burnt toffee note. 
Taste - the burnt toffee dominates the chocolate. 
Palate - medium bodied with a creamy yet dry burnt middle section which follows 
Overall - could be a dry stout. Or could also be a porter of sorts. Very rich and tasty. Big for the ABV.

A deep dark stout with a very thin mocha head. In aroma, sweet fruity chocolate malt with light grassy hops, light licorice, pleasing. In mouth, a tart chocolate malt with light acidity, light cherry, light bodied but nice overall. On tap at Saint Bock.

Pours super black with barely any head. Aroma is minimal but includes coffee and burnt toast. A mouthful is medium bodied with a watery finish. Easy drinking and delicious with my St. Patricks corned beef dinner. Flavors of coffee, milk chocolate and roasted grain are light.

A very good dry stout. Dark brown, nearly black, in color with a cream-colored head. Aroma is roast and dark chocolate. Flavor is roasted malt, sweetness, coffee, chocolate, and some hops on the finish. Smooth, creamy palate.

(bottle) deep brown colour with a frothy beige head. aroma of heavy margerine and yeast, pure diacetyl, with some notes of roasted malts and oxidized meat. flavour is mostly roasted malts and caramel, very sweet, with only a hint of butter and some toffee. medium-bodied with average carbonation.
Foam disappears rater quickly, but the taste is full, dark, dry and roasted. Overall a very good dry stout

A darn tasty dry guy if every one made me too shy to cry. Bliggity black with the slightest crimson hints peaking through, an effervescent light tan head atop er. Roast malt, smoke, rich dark chocolate, slight coffee, leather and some earthiness tantalize the beak. Taste is essentially the same, big bold flavour with a burnt sweet cocoa taste lingering. This is very dry finishing as expected although I do wish the body was a bit fuller and less carbonated. Overall very solid and excellently enjoyable.

Bottle: Served in a taster: Thanks Oirschot crew:
Small light brown head. Clear black red ish colored beer.
Aromas of coffee, some ash, hints of bay leaf and smoke...
Flavours of coffee, coffee roast, some caramel, some mocha, some bitters and nuts.
Aftertaste bitters with coffee and some wtery malts.
Low carbo, light creamy light watery mouthfeel, medium bodied and a watery texture.
Strange stout!

text: Bottle @eindhovensbierfestival. Almost black with a beige head. Smells and tastes sweet, roasted malts, bitter, some red fruit and chocolat.
Bottle shared by me yeah. Black colour with a small beige to light brown head. Smells sweet, liquorice, roasty, some tar. Tastes roasty, tar, slightly chocolate, watery. Thin body, medium carbo.

pretty dark, almost black, with a thick light-tan head that goes from 1-2 fingers to just a hint pretty quickly. aroma is roasted, roasted, roasted. has just a hint of that vegetal quality i only seem to ever get in bottles, which isnt dominant at all, but prevents me from rating the aroma and flavoe even higher. what is that anyway-some sort of slight contamination? i seem to experience it more with breweries that have consistency issues with their bottles...Sac, Moylans, etc... Anyway, doesnt take too much away from this tasty brew, which is opening up quite nicely. Dry roasted grain, nut, chocolate, coffee flavor. On the thin side, as the style dictates, but actaully has a nice amount of body to it. Carbonation is a bithigh, so a little swirling does lessen that a bit and smooth things out. Overall, a good beer thats just a touch rough around the edges."
Bottle @ 2nd Tuesday tasting. Aroma is roast, liquorice, coffee, light molasses. Flavour is light roast and bitterness, some coffee and molasses, some malt. Very nice.
@molen tasting. Unexpectedly thick stout, very oily and sticky beer. Taste of strongly roasted malt, coffee and some mild hops. Tasty beer.

Bottled @ de Molen tasting, small sample. Dark brown color, short head. Aroma of coffee, dark roasted malts, some mocha and milk chocolate. Dry and roasty in taste, soft bitterness. Soft carbonation, medium bodied. Great example of a dry stout.

UPDATED: JUL 15, 2015 Bottle at the De Molen second Tuesday tasting August 2014. Poured a deep mahogany with a round frothy light tan head. The aroma is big smoky roasted malt. The flavour is medium to light bitter with a roasted malt, chocolate, coffee plate. Medium to light bodied with soft carbonation. A little light and lacks body for me.

Sample at the Molen monthly tasting.
thin tan head. Chocholate aroma. Clear deep brown pour. A decent stout

Bottle shared at the De Molen monthly tasting. Pours dark brown with a small tan head. Aroma of roast, oatmeal, chocolate, caramel and fudge. Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter. Medium bodied with soft carbonation.

Aroma is rich dark malts, chocolate, espresso, fig and caramel. Taste is rich caramel malts with a creamy mouthfeel. Finishes with a slight dry body and lightly bitter finish. The water used adds nice mineral flavors that complements the grains very well. Appearance is a black body with a pearl head that retains fairly poorly.
Århus Syd: Black color with a fine beige foam. The roasted aroma. A little thin toasted flavor with notes of green pepper. Must be re-rated

December 16th, 2012 - By the very name if it, Moylans Brewery was designed to brew a Dry Irish Stout, just by the name of the brewery. And to all appearances, theyve done a wonderful job making something that trumps the classic Guinness. In visual style it is much the same, with a deep, dark brown all the way through, and a thick cap of foam on the top (though not so velvety as Guinness, it is close.) The smell is like the inside of a granary, with toasted oats and barley, like a thick and slightly burnt oatmeal, dusted with chocolate shavings and cocoa powder - addicting and satisfying. A sudsy palate delivers a beer that goes down smooth and easy (again, like Guinness), light and even ethereal. Toasted oats dominates the flavor here too, with a nice assertive maltiness that generates sweetness all the way through. This comes across as a step above Guinness at every step, with more substance, a stronger flavor, and probably more calories too.

UPDATED: JUL 7, 2014 Draft at Moylans on nitro. Black with light tan head. Aromas of chocolate, roast, light caramel. Tastes of chocolate, roast, light vanilla. Medium body with a dry finish. Creamy mouthfeel.

This rich black beer has a strong chocolate and coffee aroma. It is very much not what you expect when you taste it. Very light almost sweet flavor. It has a really unique taste. I have not really had anything like it.

Bottle a black colored beer with a beige head aroma roasted malts spicy citrus and some hops flavor roasted malts spicy laurel citrus and some bitter hops

Bottle. Jet black body, big creamy off-white head. Nose is dry ashes, licorice, dark chocolate and hints of coffee. Taste is chocolate, coffee, dry ashes, mild smoke, licorice and hints of bread. Dry finish, medium body and medium carbonation. Pretty OK for a dry stout, but not fantastic.

1pt. 6fl.oz. bottle ($5.90) from Premier in Halifax.

Very nice roasty aroma. Pours black with some brown head. Has a light bitter taste. Medium body with oily texture and livery carbonation.
UPDATED: JUN 11, 2014 Bottle. Black, frothy, brown foam, medium bitterness, medium body, oily feel, soft carbonation, & bitter finish.

schenkt zwart ondoorzichtig met minimale bruine kraag.
aroma van koffie, chocolade, moutig, zoet, gebrande en geroosterde mouten. Smaken zijn matig tot redelijk zoet, zwak bitter, niet erg sterk, licht fruitig, matig moutig. medium body, dun van textuur, lage co2, afdronk wat zoetig en iets droog.
Aardig bier maar over het algemeen te beperkt en te dun.

Bottle shared with Erwin van Moll @ Van Moll Brewpub. Black color, medium sized light brown head that diminishes fairly quickly. Aroma is malts, dark malts, roasted malts, coffee roast. Taste malts, dark malts, lightly coffee roast, a hint of leaves, soft to decently bitter. Dry finish, medium body and carbonation.
Bottle from Cotteridge Wines; dark brown pour with a big creamy tan head, light coffee aroma, taste has chocolate and coffee, some sweetness.
Ins Glas ergieß sich ein dunkel rötlichbraunes Bier mit schöner beigen Schaumkrone. Geruch röstmalzig, leicht schokoladig süß. Geschmack schokoladig malzig, leicht trocken fruchtig, Kaffee.

Bottle - Bought Aug 2011; BBE undated; Drank Jun 2012 - Opaque Black in colour. Very lively; highly carbonated. Very Malty; roasty malts, lots of coffee, caramel, some chocolate, some vanilla. Hoppy; some balancing hop bitterness. Smooth, mellow, well balanced. Dry but sweet roast malty; NOT bitter. Very drinkable. Nice Stout!

Aroma is very oaky. Like old wet wood.
Dark brown with a tan head that dissipates quickly.
Taste is very dry. very light. Sweet. Huge oak note. 
Palate is strange.... dry but also quite sweet. 
Overall this tastes exactly (like.... exactly!) like a homebrew I did which is strange because I have very little home brew skill. Maybe its good for the style but really not blowing my mind. Dry. Easy going. The huge oak note is sort of off for me.

Poured from a bomber into a pint glass. Pours a deep brown, with a massive medium brown head that lasts and leaves fair lacing. Nose is malt and coffee. Taste is malt and coffee, with a dry, clean finish. A slight sour taste on the finish, but not at all unpleasant. A rich, complex flavor profile.
UPDATED: MAR 13, 2014 Caramel, chocolate, vanilla, roasty, and coffee malt tones. Pretty thin and watery. Palatable. Pretty tasty, but not my favorite. Lacks depth.
A nice brew. Dark black pour with a huge foamy beige head. The nose is roasty and a bit smoky with espresso, chocolate and oat notes. Smooth body overall with a nice robust yet relaxed feel.
65 cl bottle @ home. Pours black with some sediment and a tan head that leaves a little lacing. Aroma and flavour are roasted malt, chocolate, vanilla, and liquorice - with a dry finish.

65 cl bottle.
Pitch black color, beige head. dry malty aroma, some chocolate and mild sourish fruits. Fruity taste as well, lactic notes, chocolate and roasted malts. Not really fond of the lactic notes here, otherwise decent.
4334

650 ml bottle.
Pours a black colour with a small beigeish head. Aroma of roasted malts, cream and licorice. Flavour of roasted malts, cream, milk chocolate and some grassy notes. Mild coffeeish bitterness and berries as well Medium bodied, smooth mouthfeel and soft carbonation. Quite rich.

650ml bottle. Clear, ruby red glowing, quasi black colour with average, foamy, half-way lasting, moderately lacing, off-white to beige head. Roasty dark malty aroma, a grainy touch, hints of dark chocolate and grainy coffee surrogate. Taste is is dry, roasty dark malty, notes of dark chocolate, a grainy touch, coffee surrogate.

Black beer under a huge, thick cream-tan head. Dry-roasted, woody nose, dry cocoa powder, wood shavings; dried green herbs, chocolate truffles; Rather subdued, mildly sweet and faintly roasted flavour. Again some dry cocoa powder, but again slighlty sweetened. Faint wood. MF betrays the lively carbonation. Dry, but far from bone-dry. Medium bodied. Good, but certainly not spectacular stout. Irish stouts usually are more burnt, and have a more pronounced acidity. Easily drinkable, but not one to remember forever.

Bomber bottle poured a clear dark brown hue w/ large creamy tan head. Big sweet roasty aromas. Initial flavor is light sweet w/ a light bitter finish. Tastes are roasted malt, charcoal, marshmallow, and chocolate. Medium bodied, watery mouthfeel, and soft carbonation.

65cl, at 5%Vol, as Moylans Dragoons Dry Irish-Style Stout, American brew, from De Hopduvel Gent, not complex dry Stout, malty/roasted and slightly fruity, balanced, hazy, good head, nice brew, yet expensive!
Heady, over worked beer with a bitter aftertaste, basement aromas, woody, skunky, leather
Not really my type of beer there are definitely better ones out there. Wont be getting this again.

Opaque Black Color, Huge Brown Head, Lots Of Lacing. Strong Toasted, Sweet Coffee, Chocolate Aroma. Taste about the same: Roasted Malt, Coffee, Moderately Sweet Chocolate. A little thin, Just A Notch Over carbonated. Slightly Sour Dry Finish. Nice. Aroma and Tasty. Enjoyed It. Recommended.

Appearance: velvety near black pour with a short tan head and average lace.  Aroma: roasty, with licorice, chocolate, wet granite, hint of herb, vanilla, and cream.  Taste: dark chocolate, molasses, soy sauce, vanilla pudding, with a bit of talc.  Finish: dry and smooth, with lingering roasty notes. Notes: For a 5% stout, this was a nice mix of drinkable and rich. Not bad at all.
bottle 650 ml @ home. Pours black with a beige head. Dark chocolate, cocoa in the aroma. Dry mouthfeel. Roasted malts, cocoa, coffee, some ash in the flavor. A bit thin but nice
On draft at RattlenHum. A nice light stout. Flavors of coffee, caramel, a little sea salt and sulfur. There is even some noticeable barley malt (what a shocker, eh?).

Bomber from Woodmans in Waukesha. Pours an opaque black with a thin brownish head leaving almost no lace. Aroma has chocolate and roasted malts. Taste is of light chocolate, some caramel and faint fruit. Light to medium bodied. Lowly carbonated and very dry. Thins out as it warms. Finishes bittersweet and quickly. Shrug? Old bottle? It was bone dry and thin without a significant flavor palate. Inoffensive but disappointing.
Sample at DØE 2013. Black with an beige head. Aroma and flavour of roasted malt, coffee, cocao, licorice and a dry finish.
UPDATED: JUL 1, 2015 Pours black with a thin tan head. Malt, caramel and cocoa aroma. Roasted malts, caramel, cocoa and coffee flavors. Sweet and a medium body with a dry finish. Nitro 3.8.
Very dark black pour with a tan head. Earthy roasted malt aroma. Sweet roasted malt flavour. Chocolate and coffee. Thin texture. Tasty berry and chocolate finish.

Pours a very dark brownish black with a small creamy tan head. Aroma is roasted malts, mild coffee, and cocoa. Flavour is roasted malts, lightly acidic, cocoa, bitter sweet and dry coffee finish. Good beer, great Flavour but a little thin.

Moylans Dragoons Dry Irish Stout has a thick, creamy tan head and a dark brown, almost black appearance, with lots of bubbles clinging to the sides and a fairly thick lacing sheen left on the glass. The aroma is of bitter coffee, dark malts, acidity, and some burnt properties. Flavor is of dark-roasted, somewhat burnt malt, acidity, black bread, and maybe cocoa powder. There really isnt much bitterness, here. Mouthfeel is light and prickly, and Moylans Dragoons Dry Irish Stout finishes dry, astringent, sweet, and easy drinking. Overall, this is most excellent, and I recommend it! RJT

Very dark brown with small beige head. Aroma is roasted malts, chocolate, little coffee, little dark fruits and a little liquorice. Flavour is roated malts, chocolate, little sweet, little dark fruits, little liquorice and a little bitter.

Draught @ Moylans Brewery & Restaurant, Novato, CA
Pours black with a light tan head. Aroma has notes of roasted malt, chocolate and caramel. Taste is light sweet and light bitter with a roasted, chocolate and dry finish. Body is light, texture is thin, carbonation is soft.

On tap at the brewpub. Pours brown with an off wrote head. Aroma of roasted grains, caramel, chocolate and malt. Flavor is sweet and malty with some berries, roasted malt and caramel. Medium body, average carbonation.

On tap at the brewpub. A small, dense, light tan head sites on top of an almost black body. Roasted, sweetish aroma with chocolate and some mocha. Full body, very soft on the palate. Dry. Roasted flavor with chocolate and some mocha, less sweet than expected judging from the aroma. Long, roasted finish. Very easy to drink, and tasteful. 130806
Tap. Pours opaque black, medium tan head, nice lacing. Aroma and flavor are roasty, cigarettes, chocolate. Medium body, creamy mouth feel.
Nice stout. Thin tan head that lingered to the end. Very dry and slightly roasty. Somewhat thin and slightly overcarbonated. Good beer.

650 ml bottle, Cardinal Pub & Bar, Stavanger. ABV is 5.0%. Pitch black colour, moderate to low tan head. Nice roasty aroma of dark malts and coffee, with hints of dark chocolate and ashes. Dry roasty flavour, dark malts and mild coffee, not very complex, but straightforward and pleasant to drink.

Bottle @ Epic Beer Fest Denver 2013. Pours a brownish/black appearance with a brown head. A touch smoky, roasty malty, chocolate, light coffee aroma. Fairly dry, a touch earthy, caramel, roasty, mild coffee flavor. Pretty tasty beer.

Bottle at Epic Beer Festival 2013. Pour is deep, deep brown, almost black with a frothy brown head and great lacing. Roasty, cocoa, light vanilla, coffee, bready, and caramelly aroma. Taste is a bit thin - roasty, earthy, a touch of caramel, brown sugar, grassy, and espresso. Light/medium body with high carbonation. Could really benefit from a thicker mouthfeel.

Torpedo bottle. Omaha.  Black color.  Medium head. Aroma is dark roasted malts, coffee bean, earth tones, vanilla.  Light sweetness.  Has a milky-like sweetness in it.  Dry finish. Creamy texture.  Smooth. Nice.
Bottle. Good vinous aroma. Black colour. Stable light brown head. The flavour has a good coffee note. Slightly thin mouthfeel, but good flavour.
Pours dark brown with a beige head. Aroma is raosted malt, coffee, chocolate, light soy and liquorish. Flavour is roasted malt, coffee and liquorish.
Flaske> Sort klar oel med et fint skumhoved. Dejlig duft af braendt malt med en fin soedme. Smagen er frisk og toer som den skal vaere. Dejlig oel.

text: Poured into standard pint, pours dark brown, near black with a finger of tan head that dissipates in minutes. Strong aroma of coffee and roasted malts. poured black with a tan head. aroma chocolate, coffee,caramel, toast, roasted malts. flavor see aroma. nice easy drinking beer

Deep black pour with a dissipating tan head and lively carbonation for a stout. Aroma has coffee and dark malts. Taste is a blend of bitter chocolate, black coffee, dark bread and smoke. Solid body with a long palate that finishes very dry. Good stout.

Pours basically black with a medium sized tan head that seems to want to fizzle out pretty quick but never really goes away. 

The aroma is appealing, chocolaty, husky with a light but ever-present roastiness akin to a dark roasted coffee. 

The flavor is fairly similar to the aroma, chocolaty with light coffee notes. Some berry and dark fruit in there isnt too bad at all. The beer has a lightly ashy flavor and is by all means a very nice presentation of the style. Its light both in flavor and mouthfeel, its dry, only lightly bitter, and its enjoyable... so basically it ticks all the right boxes for a dry stout. This beer is exactally what I expected and hoped to get when I took the bottle off the shelf.

Black,quick dimishing head leaving a frothy ring.
 Mild aroma of chocolate and light sweet roast. Light dark berry notes.

The flavor was dry, bitter and roasty with wood, smoke, vanilla and floral hops. The finish was long, dry, roasty and floral. Medium body. Ok.

Bomber. I like that its named after a WAR cavalry officer. I dont like the cheap-looking label. The brewery practically gives you the recipe. The stout itself is a great looker, big tan head, excellent lacing. But the taste doesnt match the black color. Theres slight roast, but its thin underneath. Blindfolded, Im not sure Id even guess stout.

I cannot agree with the brewers that this beer is incredibly rich in flavor.  I found it a little thin and lacking in all departments.  But, for the style I suppose its not too bad.  Its not supposed to be an imperial.  Still, I have to admit I like big flavors, and this beer was modest in that regard.  Some roast, with a little H2O coming through in the finish.  Not bad, not worth the amount of cash I put down for it, considering my personal tastes.

650mL bottle poured deep black color with a small tan head that left a nice ring on surface.  Aroma of chocolate, coffee and roasted malts.  Taste is malty sweetness and chocolate and a hint of coffee with a nice hoppy bitter finish.  Nicely balanced stout with full body and little carbonation.  An enjoyable tasting experience, highly recommended.

22 ounce bottle, no bottle date.  Pours pitch black color with a small 1 finger fairly dense tan head with nice retention that reduces to a lacing cap.  A small bit of lacing clings to the glass as well.  Aromas of big milk chocolate, roasted malt, caramel, toffee, vanilla, and some coffee.  Some damn nice aromas here with good strength and balance.  Taste of big roasted malt, milk chocolate, and caramel; with light coffee and vanilla.  Some noticeable bitterness on the finish, with lingering notes of chocolate, caramel, roasted malt, and vanilla on the finish for a short period of time.  Still quite dry as would be expected.  Medium carbonation and body; with a nice smooth mouthfeel with tons of creaminess.  No alcohol noticed at all in the taste or finish as expected.  Overall, this is the best dry stout I have ever had.  For 5%, this has tons of flavor with a great mouthfeel.

Pours jet black and a nice small tan head.  Nose is quite burnt, roasty. malty breads, earthy and chocolate.  Flavor is roasty and dry with heavy notes of chocolate and roasted malts.  Dry flavor as expected.  full body.  Good beer.

On cask at Moylans. Pours black with a finger of beige creamy head. Not much of nose on cask, but do get roasted malts and hints of chocolate and coffee. Tastes of roasted malts, very creamy, medium bodied for a stout with a very dry finish. Overall a good dry stout, has the flavors and mouthfeel I am looking for in a good Dry Irish Stout.

Bottle. A nice and light tan coulored head, almost three fingers high giving the beer a nice look. Aroma of mostly roasted hops and some coffee. Also some malt and sweetness in scent. Tasted a lot of coffee and had a distinct coffeebitterness and a roasted flavour. Some sweetness in the after-taste, but still much coffee.

This was an unexpected pleasure today.  Very dark with a decent light head.  There are enough flavors to keep me guessing:  hints of chocolate, roasted malts, and sweeter than the dry finish.  I thought that a "stout" would be thicker and boozier than this. Worth another try.
Tap. Pours black with a creamy beige head. Roasted malts and off bacon surround the nose. A boring mix of chocolate and smoked meats in the taste. Below average
Pours deep brown/black with nice roasted malt and cocoa notes.  The mouthfeel shows off deeper roasted malts and a bit of light chocolate.  It finishes nice and dry.
Lovely milky crema head. Quite sessionable. Lovely balance with roast barley notes dominating. Only complaint perhaps a little too much sweetness and thin but nice none the less

Bottle. Pours black with a nice frothy tan head. Aroma of chocolate, coffee and roasted malts. Flavor was medium bodied and smooth with dark roasted malts, chocolate, coffee and had a slight bitterness with a dry and roasty finish.

22oz bottle 6/18/11 (Binnys Downers Grove)-Pours black with a two finger tan head. Aroma of roasted malt, coffee, and cocoa. Taste of roasted malt, coffee, and finishes with some bitterness. This medium bodied brew is not bad and pretty well balanced.

Black pour with a long lasting, tall, tan head.
Soft roast malt aroma.
The flavor is lightly bitter with a soft dryness.
O.K. , but nothing special.
Light, creamy, roasty. Almost a silky mouthfeel. Loads of sweet roasted malts, cocoa, light coffee finish. An impressive stout. There is a crapload of flavor packed into this brew.

One of the best things about this brew is that you can, quite easily, consume an entire bomber by yourself without fearing boozy, slurred ramblings to come.  Dragoon provides all the necessities of a solid stout, with a light texture and teensy ABV, fairly nice amidst the sea of huge Impy Stouts.  Nutty, roasted, and coffee-laced, the "dry Irish" part comes through with a bitter, charred-oak and british malt front that slides into a smoky, coffee finish.  This bottle plunges into the depths of Big Stout tastiness without the drunken baggage, an admirable feat.  (3/3/09)

Taste :  Butterscotch with roasted malt and hops. Light hints of smoke with nice dark chocolate on the finish. Faint bitterness. Nice soft carbonation.

Overall : Highly quaffable stout. Great finish and nice nose. Not a big fan of the butterscotch but it aint too strong here. Very tasty. Nothing outstanding but a fine session stout.
Near black with a beige head.  Roasted malts, chocolate, bittersweet, toasted malts, biscuit, and light coffee.  Dry finish and slightly thin mouth.  Nice.

Bouteille de 650ml. Ce dry stout est noir opaque, la mousse est brune et durable. Le nez est exubérant, agréable, avec des notes de café, de grillé, de rôtie et des notes de chocolat sont aussi perceptible. La bouche est quelque peu mince, les notes rôties sont agréables par contre. Ce stout se boit à grande gorgée. 6/10

Le liquide a une robe noire.  La mousse foncée est épaisse, crémeuse et résistante.  Quelques traces restent accrochées au verre.  Le nez est typique de ce style : des parfums de café et de chocolat amer chatouillent les narines.  Une certaine douceur se dessine derrière les grains foncés : on peut penser à un caramel ou même à des pointes vanillées.  Le goût est dominé par une torréfaction qui se détend au contact de légères pointes chocolatées.  En bouche, le liquide, au corps plutôt élancé, me semble bien animé par un pétillement vivifiant : sa texture échappe ainsi quelques notes crémeuses.  La finale, sans étonnement, se fait sur des notes rôties asséchantes et sur des notes chocolatées amères.

Tap @ Parkway. Dark red-brown pour with a short brown head leaving heavy lace. Not much nose, medium-light body with some bitter chocolate and roasty malt. A bit watery in the finish, but nice and dry. Im a bit disappointed in this one, especially in comparison to Moylans other fine brews.

Pours a dark black color with a massive foamy head that goes from tope to off white. Nose is vinyl, potting soil, and oreo cookie crust. Moderate mouthfeel with a burnt, roasty taste, that finishes bitter. This one gushes EVERYWHERE.

On tap at The Queen Vic. Pours a dark brown with a frothy tan head leaving good lacing. The aroma is a raisin malt with charcoal and roast. Thin mouthfeel with a light roast and coffee and nice dry finish. Easy to drink a good dry stout from Moylans.

bottle.  Pours beautiful black with creamy, frothy, sustaining head with nice bubbles and lacing.  Nose is chocolate and nicely roasted, with a slight sweetness.  Medium bodied and low in carbonation, mouthfeel similar to a guinness but probably a little more full bodied, not to say there isnt a sort of thinness to this which makes it immensly quaffable and a good example of an irish stout. Black pour. Aroma is very toasty, charcoal, burned toast, bitter coffee. Very dry and toasty aroma. Some coffee notes.

Tap at AZSBF.Pour is black with a beige head.  Aroma shows notes of roast malt, chocolate, coffee, and light vanilla.  Flavor shows the same with light hints of ash and soy.  Overall body is moderate to full and finishes with roasted bitterness.

Black, with a moderate light brown head thats gone in a flash. Aroma of roasted malt, coffee and smoke. Taste is roasty, a little bitter, and just barely sweet. Body is somewhat full, but definitely a little thin for what I expected. Slightly dry, short bitter finish. Not a bad beer at all, just not great. In sum, its just a little thin in all areas

Bottle.  Pours a dark black with a thin beige head.  Aroma of roasted malt and toffee.  When you first drink it, it has a tiny hint of sweetness followed by caramel, dark chocolate and coffee flavors.  Not a completely full tasting beer, but still decent in that regard and has a definite dryness to it.  Overall I liked it a good bit, Stouts arent my usual go-to beers but when you get one like this you can certainly appreciate em.  5.0% alcohol.

Bomber from Cask Pub & Kitchen, Pimlico.  Black beer with thick tan head.  Had to pour it into 3 glasses and then decant to get even a sensible level of carbonation in the mouth.  Touch of tar but real promise of dry roasted malts on the aroma.  Bit too much tar and liquorice for me.  Not a liquorice fan.  Yes, quite dry, but some juicyness on the swallow too.  I mean its a bit meaty, it has some charcoal smoke and some dark choc and a bit of espresso coffee, but its not very impressive and Im not keen on this intense tar/charcoal/liquorice flavour.   Touch of burnt rubber on aroma too.  Not ma thang.

Dark - maybe even black - decent head.  Aroma has hints of chocolate.  Taste is of dark roasted malt with hints of hops bitterness in the background.  Finish is more of the same but with some bitterness.
Super dark brown with a perfectly thick tan, foam head. Dark, roasted malt nose. Chocolately flavor with hops. Creamy mouthfeel. Lively palate and milky, malty buzzing finish.
not much on aroma and for a stout a bit light. But the taste is terrific and it it is a well balanced brew.  A bit of a different taste for a stout I would gladly try agin.

Bomber from Dr. Capones.  Pours dark brown with 2-finger light brown head.  Nose is roasty black patent malt, Wheaties, nuts.  Tastes rich, smooth, with roasty malt, medium palate heft and complexity, and a dry roasty maklty finish.  This one is very good.

Draft on a nitro tap J Clyde.  Pours black with a brown head -- beautiful.  Aroma and flavor are roasted malt, some chocolate and vanilla, a hint of fruitiness and smoke.  Finishes quite dry.  Not a hint of bitterness.  Flavor and palate are smooth as silk.
Pours black with thick creamy tan head and foamy lacing.  Traditional notes of coffee and chocolate, though a bit subdued.  Well balanced taste, but also a bit subdued, as though watered down.

UPDATED: JAN 29, 2011 Unique beer!  Aroma was, of all things, smokey...hmmm.  Appearance 5+ BLACK... the head was a pretty light brown color.  Flavor was smokey, burnt and of strong coffee.  A little different but different can be a good thing... interesting.

On Tap and not just on Tap, On NITRO!!! As you all know, NITRO was the greatest of the American Gladiators in the classic 90s TV show. This beer was a treat and a good way to bring in 2011. It certainly beat New Years 1999 when I had to pee in a cat litter box b/c someone was hovered over the Oval Office for hours when I had to go.
Poured into an irish stout glass. Not much aromas except some roasted notes. Initial taste of roasted malts and coffee. Ended abruptly. Not too memorable.
