Small head that vanishes quit fast. Aroma and flavour are both fruity and wooden with some dark dry fruits as well as mild ashyness. Also some mild toffeeish notes in the flavour.

Bottle conditioned, 473ml from Bellingers Garage, Grove, Oxon. Black with brown head. Heavy fizzing on the pour, loads of condition, but this clearly hadnt travelled well. There is a sour, tart, off fruity flavour from the start, lip puckeringly so. I tried letting it breath but it didnt disperse. Some coal, tarry undernotes, but I failed to drink it all unfortunately due to the sourness.
Pours black with medium brown head. Aroma is roasted coffee, caramel, chocolate and breadyness.  Taste is bittersweet.  Light  body with soft carbonation.  mouhfeel Very good.
On tap.  Dark brown color.  Chocolate dry roast flavor.  Very balanced and smooth.  Great!

Pitch black with a decent light brown head.  Roasted, somewhat sour aroma.  Medium bodied with a slightly sweet, roasted flavor.  Finishes like a medium roast coffee.   Overall a very good and easy drinking stout.

Bottle.  Pitch black beer with a strong light brown head.  The aroma is sweetly roasted with hints of oats and sourness.  The flavour is sourish and roasted with a watery thread and dry finish.  Overall a reasonable roasted and slightly sour tasting stout.

A thick black pour with a smallish but substantial tan foam.  Aroma is sweet molasses and chocolate.  Flavor begins earthy with funky peat.  Coffee and  chocolate with some heavy cream.  Some very rich malt is in here.   A rich feel.
Bottle from pikapp327.  Dark pour with a light brown head.  Aroma is very roasted, dark fruit, a little chocolate, and lots of malt.  Taste is more of the same but with an added coffee flavor.

Aroma:humel malt kaffe tørv lime Ud.:kaffesort klar Skum:nøddebrun tæt langh  E.smag:sød lidt sur moderat bitter meget Krop:let medium For.:olie  Brus:blød 
f 75cl f1fan 22/10-10

Clean toasty roasty chocolate nose, Deep brownish black, foamy dark tan head.  Rich chocolate malty sweetness, nice balance with the roasty malts.  Medium body, smooth carbonation, slightly roasty sweet malt finish.  Very clean pronounced flavors, great beer.

(Bottle, Stockholm Beer Festival, 9 Oct 2010) Black colour with brief, beige head. Malty, roasted nose with chocolate, dark bread and smooth coffee hints. Malty, roasted taste with notes of coffee, chocolate, dark rye bread and a dry finish with a generous coffee bitterness. Medium body with smooth, velvety moutfeel. Quite dry. Well balanced and very tasty. Nice beer.

22oz bottle poured into an English pint at 47°.  Color is deep black with good carbonation and a small tan head.  Aroma is a dry roasted scent.  Medium bodied with a smooth mouth feel, a mild roasted malt flavor that lets chocolate and coffee come through. After taste is dry with a burnt toast flavor lingering.  Overall this is a very well done Dry Stout.

Bottle 22fl.oz.[ Trade by cgarvieuk ]. Clear dark black brown color with a large, frothy to creamy, good lacing, fully lasting, beige head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, roasted, coffee, dark roasted. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet, light acidic and moderate bitter with a long duration, berry - fruity - coffee tart. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20101022]

Bottle, BoE. I maybe didnt do this justice by having at last on a night of tastings, but for me it was overly dry and sharp, coating the tongue with a licquorice feel. Nice appearance and maybe one to come back to when I get the chance.

Love this beer. Although I may be partial because I love dry irish stouts.. Great head retention, nice lacing. Smell is moderate (typical for this style). tastes like the true craft version of Guiness. smooth on the palate. Will definitely seek again. well done..

22oz bottle from Bevmo 
Appearance: Pours almost black ruby brown with a nice beige head and some lacing left in the glass 
Aroma: Toasted malts, rich dried chocolate and coffee 
Taste: Roasted malts, rich chocolate flavors with some hop bitterness in the finish. 
Very nice. Clean and refreshing.
NO2Very muted and mellow.  A bit watter in flavor but perfect on the palate.  Coffee in the great dark malt.  Needs a bit more flavor but great for what it is

22 oz. brown bottle. Specs. Corpus Christi, TX. A black beer with a nice head that falls rather quickly. The aroma has ash-smoke, roasted, and some underlying layers of chocolate. The taste is lightly roasted with a thin almost watery palate and honestly as far as flavor wise this is a pretty neutral tasting beer.

Bomber. Pours black with big tan head. The aroma is very roasty with some hints of fig, ash, cocoa, and beef jerky. The flavor is also straightforward roastiness with a little bit of a granola-like malt backing. There is just a touch of earthy bitterness in there. The finish is surprisingly silky with a distant note of ash and Craisins. This is a very drinkable stout.

Bottle, Liquor World in Fayetteville. Deep brown pour with a nice cap of tan bubbles. Viney molasses aroma, cocoa powder and burned marshmellows. Slighty chalky dry roast flavor with a briney oyster-liquor quality. Pleasant soft mouthfeel with a bit of substance, a rather abrupt finish. For an American bottled beer it is surprisingly rustic and unpolished in character; a good thing in this case.

Bottle at home ... foamed a bit on pouring ... dark black ... big bubbly tan head ... light toffee dry malt roast nose... little too fizzy as many US beers are... some of that american malt in not so fond of ... loads of dark fruits ..... some licorice ... deep roast ... decent enough
Bottle. Pours black with tan head. Nose and taste of chocolate, coffee and roasted grains and malts. Dry finish, as youd expect from the style.
Sample at the brewpub on 8/8/10. Black pour with a medium tan head. Roasty malt nose with chocolate and a bit of metal. Thin roasty flavor with some chocolate and a dry finish.

~Coffee and roasted grain aroma with dark chocolate. Grainy.
~Pours dark black with ruby highlights. Thick moussy brown lasting head.
~Roasty coffee flavor with acidic roasted bite, bitterness from roast.
~Med body with med CO2, smooth with soem acidic bite, chocolatey roasty finish.
~Excellent stout!! Creamy and delicious! Easy to drink and oh so tasty.
Black color with thick beige head. Great smoky peaty aroma. Taste of roasted espresso with spicy hopiness.

/when I first got this, I looked it up and found it was in the database twice. I sent feedback through proper channels and, lo and behold, it is now in there correctly. I did not have to start a thread in the forum whining about it and it was still. Moral of the story: the system works!

This is a rather nice looking stout, It pretty much looks like a nitro pour Guinness w/o the horrible tragedy that is nitro. That is what I like to see and the good folks at Moylans deserve a pat on the back for doing an outstanding job. Overall, this is a very nice dry stout. It is pretty par the course for the style, roasty but not terribly bitter, dry yet balanced and very drinkable. Carbonation is mild but enough to add just a bit of interest. It might be lean a bit toward the watery side but its really rather flavorful, esp. considering the gravity. I would way rather have this than another syrupy mess of an imperial stout. If there were 4% alcohol this would be damn near a textbook example of the style. Nice work Moylans!
Bottle. Black with a small head. Dry and roasted with a medium body. A big hitter considering its comparatively low strength. Recommended.

Bomber.  Pours murky, dark brown, fairly viscous.  Body is medium full, textured but with a short finish.  Flavor has dark chocolate and decent roastiness.  Finish is dry, with flashes of mocha and coffee.  Good, but standard; however I have thoughts that I have underrated this one.  Ill make sure to return back to it again.
Dark brown, black, thick frothy tan-brown head.  Aroma is roasty, green coffee.  Taste is dry roast, coffee beans, roasty bitter malt, a bit thin in body.

Very spewy when opened. Also, I just invented the word "spewy" . Black, big brow head. Smells surprisingly sweet, with a lot of chocolate in the aroma. Flavor is also pretty chocolatey, and some coffee. The finish is kinda dry. Not what I was expecting for a dry stout, but enjoyable nonetheless.

Tap at Rattle N Hum.  Deep black pour with a thick creamy tan head.  The nose is very nice.  Rich and aromatic with a lot of dry cocoaish malt character.  Dry palate with a slight kiss of cherry behind the cocoaish malts.  Nice lingering roastiness.  A little bit of light herbal spice on the finish.  Tasty pint.
bottle pours black with a medium tan head.  Nose is heavy chocolate and roasted malts.  Flavor is chocolate and a very dry finish with light hops and burnt malt.

Black pour, large dark tan head.  Very chocolate dominated, roasty aroma.  Smooth mouthfeel, but slightly thin feeling.  Lots of dry chocolate, for some reason it reminds me of milder Tootsie Rolls.  Theres some coffee and ash, but overall its just smooth chocolate.  This tastes quite nice, but lacks much in the way of complexity.

Pitch black with oily swirling off-white head. Aroma is of chewy candy bar caramel and light smoke. Flavor is thin, but roasty malt and full mouthfeel. Very nice, but not as poundable as I believe and Irish stout should be. Bottle from Woodys Smoke and Brew, Franklin, TN
6/26/10.  Sampled at the Tally Tasting 2010 courtesy PorterPounder.  A nice mild Irish stout. Cant complain!

Aroma heavy on roasted malt, toasty and biscuity. Black in color with little to no head and no lacing. Slightly bitter with virtually no residual sweetness. Full bodied with low carbonation and an extremely dry finish. Nice toasty character but little else.

Thanks to PorterPounder for sharing this one at the Tally Tasting.  Pours dark brown with a tan head.  Nose is roast, some coffee, earth, and hops.  Flavor is same.  Lingering dry earth and roast into finish.  It is a dry stout for certain.

Tallahassee Tasting at Proof/Liquor Loft - 22 oz bomber - picked up at Hop City in Atlanta. Dark black pour, nice thick khaki head. Nice coffee-like aroma. Flavor has some decent coffee notes, some nice black earth essence and the mouthfeel has that nice chalkiness i like in my dry stouts.

The aroma is kinda toasted coffee. It pours dark brown with a light brown head, mostly diminishing.  The taste is dry, light to medium bitterness. The body is light, the texture a little creamy but thin, the carbonation average.

22 oz. bottle. Pours a thick, but short lived, mocha head, over a clear, dark brown (SRM 35 body.....nose is  heavy coffee, light cocoa, bit of toffee....taste is coffee, light bitter chocolate, light finishing hop bitterness, dry throughout.....mouth feel is thick, carbonation makes for a creamy sensation. This meets the style quite well and has every characteristic needed. It is a very nice Dry Stout. BJCP 7/3/15/5/8

Moylans Dragoons Dry Irish Stout--2010 22 oz. Bottle.  5.00% ABV.  28 IBUs.  (4.0 / 5.0)  Thin tan thin lace head.  No sediment.  Clear dark ruby black pour turns opaque dark black.  Rich roasted burnt mild floral hop front.  Dry sweet cloying crusty burnt mild coffee cocoa earthy Stout body.  Refreshing tangy mild hop bitter black malt citrus hint end.  Sampled 5/30/2010.  2 @ $3.99 Each.

Bomber from Total Wine, Durham. I was very much in the mood for a super-dry papery as hell stout. This bottle must have been well past faded, since it was thin bordering on watery, with a mouthfeel that underwhelmed to say the least. Bland flavors remained, and I had to strain to detect much going on beyond the basic style-by-numbers. I recall enjoying this far more in the past, and will certainly try (and possibly rerate) again.

Bottle from way back when? Aroma is spot on, light roast, touch of sour cream, very nice.  Flavor follows, its dry =), lightly roasty, touch of nuttiness, faint coffee, very well balanced.  Supremely drinkable, dry, almost no carbonation.

Pours deep black into an English pint.  Huge tan head with excellent retention craters and recedes to coat surface. Chocolate covered pit fruit aromas. Thin and sweet upfront turning smoky and chocolaty in the dry aspartame finish.Earlier Rating: 4/5/2010 Total Score: 3.5Pours deep black into an English pint.  Huge tan head with excellent retention craters and recedes to coat surface. Chocolate covered pit fruit aromas. Thin and sweet upfront turning smoky and chocolaty in the dry aspartame finish.
Black with a decent beige head. Aroma is of grain and roasted malts. Taste is very roasty.

Bottled at Monks Café Wallingatan, Stockholm.   Black with small lead. Evident licorice aroma. Dry and fairly light bodied with clean, hard mouthfeel. Heavily roasty with plenty of coffee, slight resiny bitterness. he hard mouthfeel reduces the drinkability.

Bottle. Dark with a film in center. Plenty if lacing. Sweet and nutty aroma. Coffee and sweet roasted malts as well. Burnt flavor. Plenty of roasted malts. Lots of coffee too. Long bitter aftertaste. Crisp dry and bitter. A little more body would be nice.

Dark brown, cola-looking beer - nose of chocolate, roast, tobacco leaves, a touch of minerals, faint butterscotch/diacetyl - flavor is semi-dry, with quite a bit of dry cocoa and chocolate flavors - moderate sweetness through the middle - a semi-acidic and metallic character develops late that is really off-putting - some boiled vegetable character near the finish, too - starts off decent, but ends up seriously flawed.

Bomber poured into a pint glass. Brownish black with a creamy tan head. Solid roasty aroma with some vanilla bean influence, maybe a little peat and caramel. Flavor is nice and roasty with light caramel sweetness and some dark chocolate as it warms. Minor acidity and a dry finish make this nicely drinkable. Another rock solid example of a classic style from the Moylans/Marin braintrust.

Opaque, black, with some ruby highlights and little lacing. Modest chocolate and roasted coffee aromas. Maltiness turns from roasted to burnt on the tongue, with a hint of hops bitterness. Medium body, well carbonated, and a chocolate sweetness in the aftertaste.
Tap @ Rattle n Hum - sweet and chocolatey and molasses. Fresh and snappy flavor. Smooth and some carbonic sourness. Would like to see this on a nitro tap.

22oz bottle. Pours a black body with an inch thick, creamy and fizzy, dark brown head that dissipates quickly and leaves a nice lacing. Aroma is solid and abundant. Lots of roast and chocolate. A bit of a hard roast in there with some fresh espresso and earth with just a trace of vanilla. Flavor is similar, although the simplicity of the aroma seems more appealing than the flavor. Lots of roast with some burnt ash and espresso along with plenty of dark chocolates. A touch of milky sweetness and smoke before this finishes with some minerally earth and plenty of dry coffee roasts and cocoa. Very dry, actually with a light to moderate bitterness. Fairly lengthy aftertaste after a light to medium body and higher carbonation. Overall, a solid dry stout. The aroma and flavor were very similar in that there were tons of dry roasts and coffees with plenty of dark chocolates and cocoa. I think the aroma worked better on this, but the flavor was still plentiful. Very enjoyable beer.

UPDATED: JUN 15, 2010 22oz bottle, unknown date.  Pours very very dark brown/black with a small one finger brown head.  Doesnt leave much lacing or retains only a ring and light wispy covering.  Aroma is roasted, almost burnt malts, some smoke, chocolate and coffee.  Flavor is dark chocolate, roasted malts, and a bit of lingering coffee bitterness.  Mouthfeel is medium bodied, low to medium carbonation, starts to become flat.  While this isnt terribly complex, it is tasty and very drinkable.  If it didnt flatten out so much as it warmed it would rate a lot higher.

Poured dark ruby with tiny cherry-red head.  Aroma is very weak, slightly chocolatey.  Very light mouthfeel, highly viscous, unusually high carbonation.  Very slight sweetness and practically no bitterness.  Dissolves into a very slight chocolate aftertaste.  Not bad, but a little lacking in flavor.
on nitro-pours a tigh light brown head that laces and black color.  Aroma is dry dark malt-roasty/cocoa.  Taste is ashy, dry dark malt-roasty/cocoa.

Dark brown, not much head.  Raost-accented nose with chocolate is both robust and appetizing.  Light, quaffable body.  When cold, it remains full on the palate but if allowed to warm the beer thins out a bit.  Chocolatey, with roasty accents, and just enough dryness in the finish.

22 oz bottle.  Pours a clear dark brown, almost black, body with a small fizzy light brown head that completely vanished very quickly.  The nose is very dry and chocolaty with lots of roast and coffee grounds.  The flavor is very roasty and dry with lots of bitter black coffee notes.  A nice bright kick of hops late on the finish really rounds things out nicely.  Mouthfeel is light bodied and dry with nice light fizzy carbonation.  Maybe not the craziest or most thrilling beer, it doesnt scream for attention from geeks, but this was really solid for the style.

I love me a good stout, and this one fits the bill. Black color with a small head. Aromas of coffee and chocolate. Nice full flavor, moderately bitter. Palate is a bit thin, but overall I think this is a decent stout. Earlier Rating: 9/18/2008 Total Score: 3.6Black with a thick head, exactly the way a stout should be. Rich chocolate and coffee aroma. Taste is a bit weak and watery. I taste more yeast than anything else. But there are some nice coffee/chocolate flavors in there as well as some molasses. Not completely dry. Way too thin on the palate for my taste. Thin and a bit fizzy too.

22oz. bomber served in a shaker pint. Poured a deep brown/black with a finger of white head. Chocolate malt in the aroma. Light to medium bodied. More toward the chocolate malt than roasted barley in the flavor. The roasty flavor came out more as it warmed. Not a lot of hop bitterness, just some to round out the malt. Dry malty finish. Pretty sessionable. Decent Dry Stout.

Bottle - Pours dark black with virtually no head. Dry, with smooth roasty flavors on the nose, but really not that much to smell. Taste is a little smoky up front with some roasty malts. Smooth, but not bitter, this is enjoyable but not remarkable.
Aroma of hops, black with a light brown head that dissipated rather quickly.  Flavors of Roasted hops, and coffee.  It was a bit lighter than expected, but overall it would make a good session stout.

Aroma is smoky with a firm overtone of unsweetened chocolate and a roast coffee undertone. It pours a deep, opaque sable that is just a shade above black and has a thick, fine-bubbled, fairly persistent buff head. Flavor is smoky and fairly chocolaty, not sweet and just a teeny bit yeasty. Texture is fairly smooth, a bit chalky and fairly fizzy, a bit thinner than I expected but not disappointing.

22oz bomber from Springhill in Little Rock.  Near black pour with a quickly receding tan head.  Aroma is mostly fresh coffee with some hints of bitter chocolate.  Flavor is light coffee, bakers cocoa and light malt sweetness.  Thin to medium body and mouthfeel.  Short, dry finish with just a bit of a lingering coffee finish.

22. Pours jet black with a dense, creamy, pocked dark tan head that really sticks around, leaving plenty of lace. Rich, forward chocolatey nose. Lots of toasted malts and roasty bits in there as well, but primarily a powerhouse of bitter dark chocolate. Earthy hops play against that. Fairly light body, doesnt get ashy or chalky, carb is understated. Dark chocolate mid-palate, with roast, toast, and earth in support. Mild dark earthy finish. Classic dry stout, very well executed. If theres a new twist to it, it might be the forwardness of the american ingredients, but, really its more of a nod to the classics of the style.
Nose is coffee, chocolate, peat, deep brown, small coffee  coloured head. Taste is light mocha, some malt. Light bodied, some bitterness. Okay.

22oz bottle.  Smallish brown head atop black body with brown edging.  Aroma is moderately sweet, roast/coffee, chocolate, some brown sugar, light cinnamon.  Taste is medium sweet, roast, some nut, light chocolate.  Light-medium body.

Pours a very dark black color with a big, creamy tan head. Aroma has a strong roasted malt note composed of a heavy coffee and milder chocolate with some very light floral hops at the very end. Flavor starts off with a smokey presence that fades to a sweet roasted malt, light coffee, some mild raisin fruitiness in the middle and rounds out with a bitter sweet chocolate ending. Brew has a modest body with a high fine carbonation that retains the tan head very well. Overall a good stout  that transitions to a varied collection of flavors.
From notes. Dark brown/black, tan carbonation. Roasty malt and bittersweet chcolate. Dry and easy to drink. Medium body, balanced. Not very complex, but a tasty, sessionable stout.

pours black, off-white head
aroma, chocolate malts, light smoke, grainy; oat.
flavor, dry mouthfeel, med. carbonation, chocolate with hints of lactose like mocha palate. Finish is dry chocolate, no sign of bitetrness, light palate with a nice chocolate end. Light at 5abv but everything meshed together gives a nice balance and complexity. Really enjoyed the chocolate flavors.

1pint 6oz bottle, pours a jet black with medium tan head. Aroma of roasted malt, dark chocolate and coffee. Flavour is a nice balance of sweet chocolate and bitter coffee, with the bitterness lingering. Very silky and creamy mouthful. Nice stout, but the bitterness is not done very well...

Bottle: &nbsp Black, darker than expected, large spritzy light brown head, spotty lacing. &nbsp Faint burnt malt nose, slight lactose like sweetness. &nbsp Might say its got a good roasted malt base. &nbsp Slightly dry, a little thin (expected for the style). &nbsp This one lives up to its name. &nbsp Just wished I had some shepards pie to go with it. &nbsp Lingering roasted malts. &nbsp Not bad, light, slightly dry, fairly sinple yet clean and clear for the style.

Ive always known this as Dragoons at my local pub, so even before I knew it was called "dry" I always marveled at how dry and sophisticated it is. This one takes an eternity to pour, so it requires a patient bartender. Its worth the wait though. This one is not about complexity, but character. A pub stout in a suit and tie.

22 oz bottle. Pours black with a creamy tan head. Aroma is dark roasted malt with a bit of coffee and chocolate. Flavor is a nice balance of sweet chocolate malt and bitter roasted coffee. Medium to full body with average carbonation and a long dry finish. Overall a really nice Stout, lots of flavor and very rich for a 5% beer.

Bottle at Volo 
Appearance:  dark brown brew, mid plus top. 
Nose:  complex: dry smoky , woody with brown malts , roasty dryness , slight acidic notes , licorice. 7+
Flavor/Palate :  brown soft character with roasted barley in the centre, bit of alcohol. Nice stout.
Bottle at Volo.  Pours a dark brown verging on black with decent mocha head.  Very roasty nose; flavour is roasty but sweeter.  Dry, moderately bitter finish.  Good.
On cask at Coles cask fest.  Black with Caesar, with a white bubby head.  Stout aroma, but above average mouthfeel.  A bit sourness in it.  Drinkable but still not that great a stout.

Cask @ Coles Cask Event 2009. Pours dark black. Dry roasted malt aroma, hints of chocolate. Taste is roasted malt dominated, dry, extremely well balnced. Medium mouthfeel. One of the better of the event

Totally dark appearance with a small, khaki colored head and modest lacing.  Nutty, roasted coffee bean aroma.  Mildly sweet taste with notes of licorice, nuts and bitter chocolate.  Medium bodied, well carbonated mouthfeel leading  to a lingering finish.
Dark brown more than motor oil color black. Nice tan head, good lacing. Nose is overly malty for me. taste is nice roast and malt and burnt grains, but a bit thin. Overall very drinkable.

22 oz bottle from Spirits RB. Poured a thin black body with a smaller tight foamy beige head. Aroma was odd to put it nicely. Notes of vinegar dominated with chocolate, soy sauce, rotting dark fruit meat and roastiness. The flavor had a serious acidic vinegar soy flavor to it, but luckily that quickly dies down and some roasty and grainy flavors take over. Still not that great of a beer.

Bottle. Pours a real dark brown/black,thick brown hued head with good retention. Strong malty aroma. Kind of earthy flavor to the malt, reminds me of sunflower seeds. High mouthfeel with medium carbonation.

"Dry" accurately describes this stout.  The truly excellent flavor dissapates into the background about five seconds after swallow.  But thats OK, it is what it is, and what it was is good.  Reasonably priced.
Solid black, thick oily brown head. Aroma of dark chocolate, vanilla, oat, and mocha. Taste is rich with mocha coffee. Medium body and carbonation. Bitter cocoa finish.
Bottle.  Pours a black body with a tan head.  Sweet malty body, with a dry nitro whip like texture and a dry bitter coffee with some roasted notes.  Caramel accents a dry bitter finish.  Decent.

22 oz bottle purchased at Blue Max in Burnsville, Minnesota. I poured this beer at GABF 2009, I enjoyed it, and really wanted to give it a full bottle rating. Pour is dark brown black, ruby hints with a well formed 3 inch khaki head. Pretty beer. Aroma dry roasty maltiness, charred coffee and a really nice soft cocoa sweetness. Inviting nose. Taste is the nose, dry roast malt, nice soft milk dark chocolate sweetness and a great mineral aspect to the finish. Palate is medium, high, almost spritzy carbonation. Easy drinking and well made stout.

RnH: The name looked like Dragon and I got pumped, Ill be honest.  The beer disappointed.  It smells and looks like iced coffee... maybe some roasted coffee beans.  The body was thin almost watery... quickly dissipating medium/high carbonation.
Dry, cocoa, coffee, medium-light body and good feel, with a little husky grain and honey. Looks great.

Burnt to a crisp. That is how to best describe this brew, which I had last night from the cask at Rattle n Hum. Nose of burnt wood, expresso coffee, dark chocolate. Flavors reinforce the aroma, lots of dry roastiness and dark maltiness. Notes of coffee. Smooth and rich. If you like this style (which I do), you should really like this example.
Strong espresso nose with burnt and toasty coffee beans.   Taste is burnt wood, cocoa, espresso, and mud.  Mouth a bit chalky but lacky much depth.
Hearty body. Dry and sweet. Not a lot of distinguishable characteristics, but a nice drinkable beverage.

Near black pour with a thick brown head.  Some nice bubbles of carbonation from the bottom of the glass.  Aroma is heavy chocolate and milk/lactose.  Nice mouthfeel but a bit bubbly.  Flavor isnt quite as chocolately as the aroma would imply, but there is a nice roasty backbone to this one.  Quick finish, lingering bitter chocolate.  Pretty good brew.
bomber - pours thin, black with tan head on the edges; aromas of chocolate and mossy dirt; very nice on the palate with mildly rich , dry finish; nutty and chocolaty
Bottle thanks to swalden28.  The smell is coffee, chocolate, dry, and little roasty.  The look is brown to black in color not too much head.  The taste is light bitterness, roast, and coffee.

Many, many 1oz samples whilst pouring for them @ GABF09. Restrained nose of coffee and belgian chocolate. Flavor is  initially pretty earthy leather, quickly segueing to a nice bitter, dry chocolate and a little fruitiness. Great stuff.
Bottle thanks to swalden. Black pour with beige head. Aroma is light chocolate, with some smoke and BBQ. Flavor is ash, smoke. Kinda fell flat on the flavor.
bottle thanks to swalden.  blck with a cream head.  nose is coffee and chocolate.  nice on the palate with a flavor of coffee and chocolate.

Draught at Beer in the Park.   Black color with a modest tan head.   Dry roasted malt and dark chocolate in the aroma.   The flavor is mostly dry and roasty with a light caramel sweetness to make it interesting.   There is enough body to feel good in the mouth with the roast, but its still not very heavy or sticky.   I guess dry stouts can be pretty good when not served on nitro.
( 22oz bomber thanks to swalden28) Pours dark brown with great lacing and nice tan bubbles. Nose is cocoa, unsweetened chocolate, and a creamy body. If this was sweeter I think it would be superb.
( 22oz bottle )  Pours a dark brown body with a small beige head.  Aroma of roasted malt, cocoa, and coffee.  Flavor of roasted malt, coffee, peat, and earthy hops.
bottle, thanks to swalden28,dark brown color with a nutty coffee aroma, dry roast and chocolate flavors

Bottle. Pours a dark black with tan head. Aroma of nice dark roast and malt. Flavor of some dark roast, malt, some faint fruit. Mouth feel is medium body with low-medium carbonation. Overall, not half bad!

This bottled brew from a bottle shop poured a medium sized head of foamy finely sized brown colored bubbles that were mostly lasting and left behind a opaque and an excellent lacing. The aroma was brown malt mild chocolate and dark malt. The mouth feel was weakly tingly at the start and at the finish. The flavor contained notes of mild hops dark malt and brown malt. Delicious and one I would certainly buy again.
UPDATED: SEP 12, 2009 Bottle courtesy of Swalden28.  Very dark pour. Some smell of dark chocolate. Smooth taste with hints of roasted cocoa beans. Smooth but could use more. Bitter chocolate taste.
Pours a dark black with tan head.  Aroma of roasted caramel malts, coffee grounds, faint smoke.  Similar taste, nice roasty bitterness in the finish. Lovely

Bomber shared at Scottyps housewarming tasting.  Pours a very nice black with good light brown head.  Nose of nutty roastiness, which follows in the flavor with a very nice bitter chocolate accompanied by some faint smoke.  Bittersweet finish.  Medium silky body.  Good example of style.
Pours a lasting ring of tan head with a dark brown body.  Fine carbonation.  Flavors of toasted grain, bitter coffee.  Dry and a little thin.
Thin body. Black color and modest head. Very light on roasted malt flavor for a stout. No alcohol taste.

Aroma of dry, roasted malt. Pours a black color with brown highlights. Good flavor of coacoa and roasted malt, its quite dry and theres some bitterness in the end. The body is light with a powdery texture and moderate carbonation. Im not much a fan of dry stouts, but this one is quite good.
Pours black with a big beige head. Aroma is roasted malt, coffee, and a bit of chocolate. Flavor is roast malt, chocolate, a bit of caramel, with a dry coffee finish.

Pitch black body topped by a 3" thick Baileys Irish Cream foam head. Impressive coffee roast aroma, with nice flaked barley fingers. Solid roasty body with medium-mouthfeel. Much more substantial in body and flavor than a Guinness. Outstanding, flavorful, and super quaffable Dry Stout. Pitch-perfect with a simple roastiness and nice coffee complexity and graininess that works.
Bottle. Poured a dark black body with nice head. Aroma is cocoa, coffee. Flavor is bitter chococolate, light hops and coffee. More carbonated then I thought it would be.

(22 oz. bottle via trade with BMan1113VR, thanks Andrew!) Good but probably infected...Cap comes off with a big ppffffftt!! Pours very dark brown with some garnet highlights. Very large tan head rises very quickly and takes a while to settle on each pour. Aroma of chocolate and coffee. Mouthfeel is fairly smooth and lightly oily but has a bothersome fizziness. Flavor of coffee roast and chocolate with a bit of an underlying tingly sourness that may be from infection. Lightly grassy in finish. A fairly rich and tasty stout probably under normal circumstances.

From the Jug at the GABF, Colorado Convention Center 12/10/2007
Coffee roast aroma. Small beige head. Black smooth and slightly creamy on the palate. Some bitterness in a full roast finish.

Bottle thanks to nuplastikk: Pours a mostly opaque black with a thin, wispy lacing off-white head.  Aroma of lightly sweet toasty dark malts and a touch of coffee.  Starts with good fullness and lightly sweet toasty dark caramel malts along with a drier bittersweet dark chocolate finish.  A pretty well balanced and enjoyable dry stout.

Taupe head speaks worlds apart from a bone white nitro induced pint.  Fresh roasted Colombian coffee on the nose with a touch of smoked almond.  Palate confirms as the curtains match the drapes.  Dry, but not astigently so and cerntainly not before a round malt polish makes it presence known.  Clean finish of smoke kissed malt and a touch of cacao powder.  Seamless, no edges, silky and seductive with a taste of Home lingering in the back of the throat.  Fascinating that an homage can become an affront.
93

Pour is a black with a average tan head.  Aroma is milk chocolate and a decent helping of coffee.  Flavor is a nice thick coffee with some anise and finishes with a little chocolate.  A vey slight earthy hop is left on the tounge after the swallow.  Probably not the best beer to have when its 97 degrees out but a good example of the style.

22 oz bottle thanks to emacgee. Pours a very dark brown color with a medium brown head. The aroma is quite nice; loads of rich milky coffee, roasted malts, light vanilla. The flavor is rich, earthy and full; roasted malts, oats, loads of coffee, milky flavors and vanilla. Very nice. A style I appreciate. Very drinkable.

Pours with a black hue with a medium brown hue that is lasting.
Aroma is of oats, chocolate, toffee, caramel, and some light oak.
Flavor is chocolaty, sweet in the beginning followed by a bitter oakey ending.
Syrupy texture with light carbonation.

On tap. Pours with a creamy tan head and a black body. Aroma of leather, cocoa, roast. Taste is roast, coffee beans, dry roast and a metallic finish. Nitro creamy mouthfeel...slightly bitter and very lighlty lactic.

Draft at Taco Mac. Pours pitch black with thin tan head. Aroma is dry, roasty, and toasty - almost like fresh ground coffee beans - with some notes of earthy hops. Flavor follows aroma: great example of Irish Dry Stout with lots of roast flavors, light toasty malt character, virtually no sweetness, and earthy British hops. There is a nice green, earthy hop bitterness at mid-palate that accentuates the dry roasty character. The finish is dry and much like a lightly hoppy black coffee with subtle creaminess and even more subtle sweetness. Mouthfeel is smooth and light-bodied with a strong crispness (unexpected - surprised they chose to push with CO2 instead of Nitrogen). Overall, a very good example of the style - a decent, session beer stout.

Appearance: Pours a black body with a full inch of tan-hued foam.

Smell: Roasty, earthy nose with notes of chocolate, cold coffee, burnt grains, smoked aniseed, and dark caramel.

Taste: Toasted, roasted maltiness with tastes of bittersweet chocolate, charred barley, and mild coffee in the foreground and tastes of spicy anise, smoke, and dark caramel in back. Earthy hops with a medium amount of bitterness that joins with a slight roasted grain astringency. Finishes dry and roasty with a lingering hint of roasted grain in the aftertaste.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Medium carbonation. Smooth with a slight chalkiness to the mouthfeel.

Drinkability: Paired well with the movie "The Quiet Man". Though Id like to see how this fares under a nitro-tap, its still enjoyable in bomber bottle form. Id prefer a hair more body and creaminess, but its acceptable as is. At least it isnt guilty of what so many self-labeled dry stouts are -- having almost no flavor. A pleasant, flavorful, well-made dry stout.

super friendly beer. hafta be an idjit to not like this. Poured with a nice tan head that lasts forever with lotsa lace. Aroma is just good fresh balanced stout. easty beer. Good beer. friendly beer. I want more. dark, good body. Alcohol isnt an issue. would be good  with --- just about any got damn thang.
Dark black pour with a tan head. Aroma of cocoa and roasted malt. Taste was medium body, roasted malt., chocolate and had a dry finish.

Bottle 65 cl. Courtesy of yespr/Ungstrup. Pours black and opaque with a light brown head. Aroma of hard roasted malts, chocolate and vanilla. Light in body, sweetish hard roasted malts and distinct vanilla again. Hardly any bitterness. 290509

Bottled. A black beer with a brown head. The aroma has notes of sweet malt and roasted malt as well as lighter notes of coffee. The flavor is sweet with notes of both sweet malt and roasted malt as well as lighter notes of coffee and soy sauce, leading to a dry roasted finish.

UPDATED: JAN 1, 2010 2009-10-18, cask at Ginger Man, NYC, 6-4-6-3-12=31Black color. Oxidised roasted malt aroma. Dry mouthfeel, low body strength, dark chocolate flavor. Nothing special.2009-05-29, blind tasting at Papsøs, corked bottle, 7-4-7-3-13=34Black color; small persistent creamy head. Roasted malt aroma, not very strong, cardboard, alcohol, light vanilla. Medium body strength, with roasted malt flavor, liquorice, dark chocolate, roasted nuts. Correct bitterness. The final is a bit astringent (Italian: allappante), there is too much liquorice, almost minty. Average score.

#9
Bottle. [Papso Shady blind Tasting 2009] Large thick creamy almost brown head. Good display of lacework. Black color. Aroma of dusty grain, roasted malt, mild coffee and chocolate. Over the palate came dried fruit and toasted malty notes, light nutty and sweet chocolate notes. Medium bodied with a soft carbonation. Moderated sweet flavor with some bitterness. Light lingering roasted malty finish. 7 / 3 / 7 / 3 / 15 = 3.5
#09 - Amerikaner Blind-Smagning 29-Maj-2009 hos Papsoe. Bottle. Black - offwhite head. Chocolate, roasted, berries, lactic, soapy, licorice, bitterness, thin body, coffee. OK.
I had as part of a sampler. Very dry chocolate and coffee flavors. Smooth and delicious. A little thin.
Pours out a black color with a thin tan head.  aroma is that of roasted malt and choco.  Flavor is this and rather dry.  Full of malt, sweetness with a slightly bitter coffee finish
black but not opaque under a large fizzy tan head.  roasty coffee with a hint of hops in aroma.  milky, creamy, but slightly watery palate. dry finish.  flavors of coffee and milk chocolate.

At Sudwerk Beerfest 2009. This black ale poured with a thin tan head and a toffee aroma. There is a mellow chocolate malt flavor that is rich and fruity, with some vanilla notes. This is a tasty beer.

From bottle, blind #9. Pours dark brown to black with a small tan head. Roasted malt, chocolate and mild vanilla aroma. Flavour is vanilla, chocolate and slight roasted malt. Light acidic touch. Bitter and lingering roasted malt flavoured finish. Lasting acidic touhc into the far finish.

Most Moylans beers make it my way thru the year. Ive had this one a few times the past month not necessarily because its a world class beer. The price is usually right for me and I do enjoy the flavor, and >$4 for a 22oz beer is usually hard to pass. 

The beer pours out a really nice dark black color, huge 3" thick tan head with lots of sudsy bubbles leaving behind a nice lacing pattern. Aroma is chock full of dark chocolates, roasted malts, toffee with an enjoyable touch of peat. Flavor has a nice dark chocolate bitterness to it, but I liken it to powdered chocolate out of a Hersheys tin. Light roast flavor, peat, chalk (or perhaps chalkiness would lend itself to the mouthfeel). Finishes smooth with some lingering bitterness.

Faint aroma of charred coffee and a twinge of chocolate. Malted barley comes through nicely in the taste,with that mild surrounding of bitter bakers chocolate. Not exactly "incredibly rich in flavor" infact a little watery, but pleasant enough

Pours a deep, dark brown with little to no head. Aroma of coffee and chocolate. Some flavor of burned coffee and molasses, chocolate notes. Dry, light mouth feel with grainy, coffee aftertaste. Very tasty and satisfying stout beer.

Pours brownish-black with small tan head.  Aroma of roasting coffee, some bitter chocolate.  Flavor is definitely dry, with burnt malts and harsh hops prevailing.  The liquid feels very watery as it slides around in my mouth.  A bitter aftertaste of stale coffee does not encourage me to continue drinking.  I was expecting a little more from this brewery.

5.00% bottling here (not the 4.5% that is listed in addition to this one).

Pours deep ruby to almost black with thin, light tan colored head.  Nose is somewhat weak with faint coffee grounds in the distance.  On the palate it is light bodied, with some dark chocolate and roasty flavors.  This is more of an easy drinking Irish stout than an in your face stout, and I like it for that.

Bottle.  Pitch black colored pour with a tan head on it.  Smell is roasted coffee and chocolate, little hint of hops, and plenty of malts.  Taste is very dry, leaves you wanting more.  Perhaps too dry, but  it kinda works with this.  Very roasted and coffee flavors, a bit of chocolate too.  No alcohol burn, heavily carbonated.  All in all a good sessionable stout.

Nitro pour.  Loads of toasted grain on the nose with lots of coffee grounds as well.  Great dry character, complimented excellently with the creamy sweet head.  Had to give it a 5 for palate.  I mean, what else do you want in a dry stout?  Wonderful beer.

Bottle shared with JoeTheYounger.  Pours black with a creamy beige head.  Aroma is sweet and chocolatey with some molasses and hints of dough.  Flavor is roasty and a little smoky with chocolate, grain, and a very dry finish.  This stuff is pretty thin on the palate and maybe a little watery for the style.  Good medium carbonation.
Dry spicy aroma almost like pepper with a bit of chocolate. Smoky little taste, a bit dry but not as dry as I expected. Maltiness is present.

Pours nearly opaque black with ruby colored highlights.  Large light brown head is well retained.  Aroma of chocolate milk, coffee, and caramel with a faint metallic/grassy twinge.  Dark chocolate, pecan, and roasted coffee flavor accompnied by just a touch of hops.  A little bit thin, but perfectly carbonated.  An easy to drink session stout.
A Mounds bar is not a sprinkle... A twizzler is not a sprinkle... A Jolly Rancher is not a sprinkle, sir... Perhaps in Sangria-La they are, but not here..

Poured with a nice chocolaty head and sat beautifully in the glass. A lovey brown/red hue.

I really enjoyed this stout but I thought it was too sweet to be a dry stout. I was surprised by by how light in body this was judging by how it poured, but I really enjoyed it.

Im not a fan of nitrogenated beers, but fortunately this wasnt overly evident.

Bottle from BevMo.  A very good dry stout.  Dark brown, nearly black, in color with a cream-colored head.  Aroma is roast and dark chocolate.  Flavor is roasted malt, sweetness, coffee, chocolate, and some hops on the finish.  Smooth, creamy palate.

Rudy brown color with a dark bone colored head. Grainy aromas with a hint of DMS. Thinner feel. Dark chocolate and mild vanilla flavors combine for a milk shake flavor. Seems bland. Finishes dry. Light roasted malt in the linger. A thin dry stout. A session type stout.

Bottle.  Pours opaque with a small, rocky, brown head, somewhat lasting with fair lacing.  Aroma is heavy malt (chocolate, nutty, roasted caramel), light hops (dry grass), heavy yeast (leather) with notes of dates, prunes, cola, and vanilla.  Full bodied, oily-creamy texture, average carbonation, and a dry-bitter finish.  Long duration, moderate sweetness, light acidity and bitterness.
ON tap at brewery.  Dark brown with no head.  Roasty chocolate aroma.  Milk chocolate and roasted coffee with a mild bitterness.

Pours a nice tight darkish tan head which dissipates after a short bit of time. Dark brown color. Trying to figure out the aroma. Almost like a soapy quality to it (YES, I rinsed my glass out and it doesnt smell like the soap I use anyways). Bitterness in the flavor, but not overpowering. If it was ever so sweeter it could be considered a porter. Good smooth palate.

Sampled on 3/10/2009. This dry stout pours a deep black color from a 22oz bottle. Medium sized tan foamy head, with good retention and nice lacing. The aroma is roasted malt and a touch of chocolate. A little bit of peat and fruit as well. A medium bodied dry stout. The malts are roasty and chocolaty with some dark fruit and sweetness. The hops are herbal and floral. A touch thin, but still very drinkable. Nicely balanced. Good carbonation. Smooth nearly velvety taste. Mouthfeel is full. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly bitter.
nice but flawed. I like the dark opaque look but not the thin mouth feel. its got good coffee and roasted malts. deep all around. very enjoyable.

The aroma is right for the style with coffee, chocolate, toasted malt, and earth. The appearance is dark brown with a very but head. The flavor is like the aroma with a touch of licorice. The palate is thin. Overall not bad but it is not exactly to my liking.
black body with a thin creamish colored head. coffee focused taste but the palate was a bit thin. only a 4oz taste though so might have been that.
bottle shared at February Beer Advocate stout tasting.  Pours black with no head.  Nose was roasty malt.  Taste was licorice.  Taste was thin for a stout with a dry finish.
Pours dark black with a small dark tan head.  Coffee in the nose as well as predominant in the flavor profile.  Not as full bodied as I had expected...a little thin feeling.  A decent dry stout.

Bomber courtesy of Iowaherkeye  thanks Joey!  Pours an opaque black with a 2 finger dense tan head and decent lacing.  The nose is roasted malts, ashy cocoa and milk chocolate.  The taste is burnt malt, chocolate and bitter coffee.  Medium bodied.  Decent stout .
A really nice dry stout. Pours nice and dark and drinks really nice. No head, but pure darkness. A very good brew.

UPDATED: DEC 19, 2009 [1816-20081022] 1pt6floz bottle. Dry coffee roast cocoa powder aroma. Dark dark brown red-hued body with a long-lasting foamy light tan head. [2626B-20091204] Bottle. Slightly charred roasty hamsteak aroma. Black body with a quick foamy light tan head. Roasty sweet ham malt continues in the flavour with a long finish. Medium-full body. Good, could even be thicker. (7/3/7/3/15) 3.5

Black, brown head. Lightly sweet roasty nose.Light dry roast & brown sugar profile,somewhat watery finish. Some lacing.
Nothing special

Draft @ the brewpub. Pours a black color with a longlasting tan head. Has a roasted malty chocolate aroma with some hints of coffee. Dry roasyted malty chocolate flavor. Has a long dry malty chocolate finish with some hints of coffee.

22oz Bomber  Gravity Beer Market  Olympia, WA 
Dark black color, with a thick dark malt with coffee and chocolate aromas.  The malt was deep roasty with the same flavors.  This was a very dry brew with a huge flavor.  Blended very well.   One of the better brewed dry stouts.

Bomber.  Poured brown/black with thick lasting beige head. Roasty malty aroma, with a bit of nut. Flavour is sweetish malt, with chocolate, coffee and nut. Body is light, but pleasing.  Thin sweet malt finish.  Good with food.
user_location: Munchen an der Willamette, Oregon, USA

text: Bomber. Pours black with brown highlghtts and a tall creamy head that hangs on a long time and leave some weak lacing. Aroma is lots of roast, a little chocolate, lots of heavily roasted nut notes-heavy on hazelnut, a touch of espresso and just the tiniest bit of burnt sugar. Flavor is nice and sweet roasty malt up front, dark chocolate, more roasted nuts, fresh walnuts, faint char notes, and a little earthy wood. Finish is roast, some char, bitter dark chocolate and light roast coffee. Body is medium to thin with a nice smooth, creamy texture and a really nice carbonation level. A pretty good sessionable beer, maybe a bit on the sweet side for the style, but I wont complain.

I had this on draft at the brewpub. It was served on nitro. 
The mouthfeel was creamy, the nose was roasty, the flavor was a bit roasty, but a tad thin.

Pour is a dark brown with an average, creamy, tan head which is mostly lasting and leaves a couple lace rings.  Nose is pleasant with moderately roasted milk chocolate notes dominating, light roasted grains, mild earthy coffee roast, and faint vanilla.  Flavor is dryer than expected with lots of roasted grains, moderately roasted coffee with matching acidity, faint roasted hazelnuts, and hints at vanilla and cocoa.  Palate is fair with a light to medium body, lively carbonation, and dry/creamy/watery texture.  Finishes abruptly with cofee notes, acidity, and dry roasted grains.  A solid dry stout with all the right flavors present but nothing too special.  A nice balance of roasted notes bringing only enough bitterness.  Nice example of the style.

Picked up a single 22-oz bomber at Cellars Wine & Spirits in St Paul. Pours a near opaque dark brown brew with a thin beige head that slowly dissipates an off-white ring. Aroma of toasted dark malt, some coffee and chocolate, a hint of flowery hops and light vanilla. Taste is medium bodied, toasted dark malt flavors with some chocolate dry herbs, and some flowery hops. Finish is semi-dry with a light toasted dark malt and vanilla aftertaste that slowly disappears.

I dont necessarily expect much from a Moylans which is not an IPA, so the aroma was a pleasant surprise. It just smells very good, perfectly integrated malt-focused ale. A tan, small, but lacy head covers the ebony pour. Tight, tasty, roasty mouth presence which avoids the frequent vegetal undertones stouts can have. No abusive sweetness, this one honours its name: grainy, well-roasted and very clean, chocolatey more than fruity. Light-medium bodied, comfortable carbonation is soft. All in all a demonstration of Moylans versatility.

Bottle (22oz) shared with HogTownHarry, Blankboy, jerc & mabel -- courtesy of HogTownHarry.  Appearance: Dark Black, pancake head. Aroma: Leather, smoke, chocolate and coffee. Nice. Flavour: Creamy, milky, coffee with nice carbonation.

A very well balanced dry stout.  Very roasty up front, chewy, coffee highlights with a slightly hoppy and bitter finish.  Notes of chocolate, molasses, toast and coffee throughout, a delicious, sessionable stout. Great for a winter day at the local pub.

Dark chestnut brown. Aroma of coffee, bitter chocolate, and rich burnt malt. Coffee, bitter chocolate, ashy and vegetal notes all play over the palate. Finish is very dry and moderately bitter. Delicious!

text: Dark brown pour with a small light brown head. Minimal lace.  Fresh roast coffee on the nose. Creamy mouth-feel.  Nuts, coffee, chocolate, and roast.  Slightly dry and astringent

Pours a dark black that allows some light with a thin dark tan head. The nose is roasty, chocolate and coffee roast, malty, doesn’t show the bitterness. The flavor is very stout, dark malt and roast, chocolate and coffee bitterness, waxy hops and bitter grains. Nice dry and roasty palate.

bomber. hmm. This is a pretty black bere, actually. A nice tan head forms on top along with quick and sotty lacing. The aroma is milky and nutty. I’d almost swear there was lactose involved. Dark chocolate, earth, walnuts, and prunes are here. The palate is light, but creamy enough. Man, there is so much nutty character and the finish is pleasantly dry, but not overly so. Dark, Rich chocolate is here, little hints at soy sauce, roasty coffee. This is a great, great low abv stout. this is an extra sessionable beer that sacrifices no character or complexity. I give it two thumbs up.

650 ml. Opaque with a lasting quarter inch of foam and some spotty lace. Aroma is coffee, nearly-burnt grain, and char. Flavor is mocha coffee, ashes, light sour cream and berry. Chicory and char on the finish. Medium-heavy body is watery, very lightly carbonated, and acidic-roast tingly.

Bomber.  Lovely roast nose with heavy coffee grounds and just a touch of tire air.  Noisy pour, pitch with an excitable light brown head that tires itself right out.  Taste is dry and lightly roasty with seeming ash in the after but not a lot of evidence.  Has the sort of sticky grape aspect in the mid-body but spares the lips of smacking.  Light, smooth body.  Solid daily stout, and I love dry stouts, but not very exciting.  A touch of acidity; any more and this dives under three.

Deep roasty aroma.  Pitch black, with red around the edges.  Thin head.  Flavor matches the aroma.  Roasty more then chocolaty.  Beautiful example of what a dry stout should be on the palate.  No lingering sweetness, crisp and refreshing despite being a dark flavorful beer.

Roasted malts are notable in the very sweet and chocolatey aroma.  Black body is opaque and topped by a tight, dense, fine bubbled tan-brown head that lasts well.  Chocolate and roast are both strong but balanced in the flavour.  Bitterness is somewhat underwhelming and leaves it a bit sweet overall.  Medium body with moderate soft bubbled carbonation.  Tulip glass.  Just above fridge temperature.  Bottle.  Brewery Creek.  Dec-08.

Pours a deep black with ruby accents and a light brown diminishing head. Aroma is lightly sweet with roast, coffee and herbal. Flavor is cocoa, herbal, roasty and nutty. Long fry finish. Smooth texture, medium carbonation.
UPDATED: APR 17, 2009 Pours attractive deep brown with a frothy tan head. Roasted malt and chocolate in the nose and flavor. Dry and slightly bitter finish.

Pours a pitch black with a short lived but finger-thick loose brown head - I was expecting a paler Guinness-style thick head... interesting. Head reduces to thin cover of foam on the top with some lacing. Aroma is very faint - thin toasted malt & light molasses. Tastes of very light coffee with plenty of cream, light chocolate, buttery and lightly toasty. Very faint bittering hops. Light carbonation, thin body, but quite pleasantly creamy mouthfeel. I do like the chocolaty taste here, and the thinness doesn’t bother me so much as I am expecting a sturdy but sessionable dry stout and Moylans delivers. Very nice!

Pours opaque black with a thick and lacy tan head. Chocolate  Medium body and moderate carbonation. Fills the room with chocolate, coffee and molasses. Medium body and moderate carbonation. Sweet taste of dark chocolate, nuts, coffee, maybe a little licorice. Semi-dry finish. This is a dandy little stout. Not dry, but dandy none the less.

In short: Big body, wide flavour spectrum and good hopping, an exemplary session stout. How: Bottle 22oz, tasting session with Montreal crew The look: Black body with a small tan head In long: Strong and pleasant roasted nose. Taste has pretty much all one can hope from a stout, roastiness, coffee beans, chocolate and a sweet fruity flavour that reminded me of date or date cookies. So far so good and the finish doesnt let down either ending with a tasty medium bitterness blending in very well with the roastiness. A very big body for a 5% beer. This is clearly on of the best session stout Ive had. I really liked that Dry Irish, much better than the last one, a drunk Dubliner who wouldnt give me the time of day.

Bottle pours black with a decent off white head and some minor lace cling.  The aroma is of roasted malt.  The flavor is malt, roasted, some minor weak coffee, and peat.  The palate is pretty smooth and medium.  Overall, this is OK.

This wasn’t my favorite dry irish stout.  I consider Three Floyds Black Sun Stout as the best offering that I’ve had in this category.  I would’ve liked a little more richness, with maybe some coffee or oak notes to the flavor profile.  It was alittle empty for me.

Bottle (22oz) shared with HogTownHarry, garthicus, jerc & mabel -- courtesy of HogTownHarry. Pours a very deep ruby-brown with an average size semi-lasting beige head. Aroma’s dry and roasty along with some coffee and peat. Flavour of roasted malt, coffee, light hops and a hint of peat. Dry finish. Medium to full bodied. A very good stout!

On tap at Green Dragon, this wonderfully rich and dry medium bodied brew poured a hardy brown-black body with a thick beige-tan head.  On nitro, it is fluffy, with hints of biscuit and chewy grains.  A wonderful NW interpretation of a classic style.  Yum!

Dark brown nearly black pour with a decent sized dark brown head. Has a smoky and peppery coffee aroma and has a dense taste that is mainly coffee but also some pepper and is layered with a very dry finish at the end. A surprsingly smooth and tasty brew that I enjoyed more than I thought I would.

Another bottle from Canal’s in Lawrenceville, NJ.  Very deep and opaque brown pour under a small but dense dark brown head.  Initial aroma of dark roasted coffee followed by chocolate and a little smoke.  More deeply roasted coffee and semisweet chocolate in the flavor with just a touch of dark fruit tapping at the sides of the tongue.  Creamy texture and a long, smooth finish.  A really nice beer.  Thanks to Moylan’s (or the local distributor) for making more of their brews available out here.

2008-10-22. Modest foamy tan head tops a black body. Aroma of dry malt, roasty, very light wood/chocolate. (6+) Dry roasty malt in the flavour, modest roasty bitterness throughout. Bit of sweet dark malt in the finish. Average to medium palate. (3+) Solid stout, bit dry for me. Bottle shared by HogTownHarry

Bottle (22oz).  Shared with blankboy, garthicus, jerc and mabel - my bottle.  Deep ruby-black, light brown diminishing head.  Dry, medium-roast aroma, a little treacly and herbal.  Love the taste - soft, perfect carbonation, cocoa, cream, light dry herbal bitterness and light coffee, not boozy at all.  Smooth and nice.

Black color with a thin head.  Aroma of whiskey and dry malts.  Plenty of roasted malt character.  Light chocolate.  Tastes a litlte sherry-like.  I’m a fan of this over the Ryan O’Sullivan Impy Stout.

Bottle shared by mmtmatrix.  Poured a deep brown color with some red highlights and a thin beige head that faded to a ring.  Aroma of moderate roasted malt, a hint of coffee, some cocoa powder.  Smooth, lightly sweet entry leads into a light roastiness with some soft coffee that drops right into a soft hoppy finish.  Low carbonation and thin on the palate.  Pretty basic and unimpressive, perhaps a bad bottle.

Draught at GABF 2008.
Black coloured with a medium sized beige head.
Roasted aroma dominated by peat with notes of coffee.
Roasted flavour of peat and coffee with notes of hops.
Roasted finish.
Pours wtih a black body topped by a thick head with lots of lacing left behind.  It’s malty and roasty with a slight bitter sweet chocolate note.  Full bodied and smooth.

Pours a dark brown/black with a cloudy tan head. Sweet caramel/hops and roasted coffee in the nose. Sweet malt at first in the flavor with a turn to heavy roasted dry finish with just enough carbonation.

Bottled sample. Near black in colour with medium carbonation. Aromas of milk chocolate, caramel, roasted malts, minty and woody hops, along with a hint of red grapes. Fairly choco-sweet upfront in the mouth with a lot of rich malt flavors (for a dry stout), before the mineral-like drying effect of the dark roasted malts kick in. A well put together stout, but perhaps a little sweet to be considered a dry stout. Very tasty.
Dark brown/black, chocolate, malty, roasty, little coffee, little dark fruits, little nutty, dry finish.
Getting notebook online. Bottle. Pours a good black. Malty nose. A little thin and watery in taste. Not too bad.

Pours a very very dark brown nearly black with a thick foamy tan head. Aroma is very strong chocolate malt with some serious roasted nut notes. Very sweet and not much hop presence. Just a hint of some dark fruitiness. Flavor starts out very strong on the malt and sugary sweetness, mostly like maple syrup and a bit of a smokey character. A tiny hint of a cola sort of flavor in the background, which adds to the bitterness in the finish which is very quick and very dry. Medium body and high carbonation. Decent Irish stout, a little strange in some aspects (the cola like finish for example) but not unpleasant. This one ends up a little above middle of the road.

Bomber from Jimbowood. Pours black with a big, fizzy tan head. Aroma of smoke, chocolate, coffee, dark fruits. Flavor is roasty and sour, chocolatey malt flavor and a dry finish. I’m impressed by this brew.
Huge head. Lots of caramel. Has quite a sour fruity tang to it. Chocolate, coffee. Interesting beer, not sure if it’s intentionally tangy.
Pours black body with a large tan head.  Smoky, coffee aroma.  Flavor is roasted malt sweetness and coffee.  It’s quite dry with a thin body.  Tolerable overall.
Black body huge tan head. Aroma malts, coffee, dark fruit. Flavor is sour roast, dark fruit, chocolate, and sweet malts. Decent mouthfeel. Pretty decent brew.

Thin sloppy head of varying sized bubbles.  Kind of weak aroma with some roasted malts, coffee and some grains (not oats though).  Color is a very dark brown.  Mild roasty flavor with a touch of sourness and some sweet malts.  Slick mouthfeel with a bit of dryness late swallow.  Ehh, this is not doing it for me.  An ok brew but not one that I would recommend to a fellow brew enthusiast.

Ebony body with a tall brown head. Roasted chocolate aroma. Dry cocoa and milk chocolate, very smooth body, with lingering chocolate in the finish. One solid stout, one of the best stouts I’ve had in a long time, great flavor with a mild ABV.

Bomber:  This poured a black body with a creamy, sustained tan head.  It had an aroma of roasted malt & barley, old coffee, and a splash of chocolate.  The flavor has a dark malty sweetness accompanied by coffee, roasted malt,and milk chocolate.  The finish is dry and has a touch of a burnt nut bitterness.  Not bad at all.Binny’s Beverage Depot, Orland Park, IL

UPDATED: MAY 20, 2011 My Bottom Line:
Through this silky Stouts healthy malt metabolism pulses chocolate, coffee and vanilla, a perfectly amenable and attractive blend that almost rendered this dessert lover lustful.

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A ring of foam tops the brown-tinged black.
-I have to admit the flavor profile was pretty sweet for what is billed as a "Dry Stout".
-Subtle roastiness in the finish dries out most of the dextrins.
-The aroma is very seductive, and the flavor profile delivers what was promised.
-There were no notes of sourness that some here have mentioned.
-This is very drinkable; a bomber can go down in no time.

Bottles.
Beautiful pour and great nose. taste is quite watery with a weak mouthfeel. Finish is metallic.

Bomber.  Poured deep brown with a short, creamier cap of tan head.  The aroma picked up lots of wonderful dry-roasted chocolate and toasty barley with just a little grass and piney hoppage giving a brighter impression at the edges.. well-presented!  The flavor opened with cake-like sweeter chocolates that rolled across the middle.. darker anise-inspired malts joined at the core as well as a smooth, rolled oat-like sweetness.. finished with dry chocolates and a touch of coffee & pine bitterness.  Medium-bodied and dry as advertised on the palate with low, but complimentary bitterness.. carbonation was higher, and that worked too.  Nice one.

almost black in color with a tan head- good retention. Aroma: Roasted malt, light coffee and dry chocolate, with a hint of earthy hops.  Taste is roasty, with some dry chocolate and moderately sour for the style.  Body is light to medium, and the finish is dry with some light lingering tart grain.  This is a pretty decent dry stout- was a bit suprised by the accentuated sour character.

Bomber poured a clear dark brown nearly black with a small lingering brown head. Aromas of coffee, bitter chocolate, light vanilla and light fruittiness. Palate was light bodied and smooth with a lightly dry finish. Flavors of coffee, bitter chocolate, roasted malt and a hint of vanilla with a smooth dry roasty finish.Earlier Rating: 6/14/2007 Total Score: 3.7On tap @ Moylans poured a translucent dark brown with a large lasting creamy tan head. Aromas of milk chocolate, mocha and vanilla. Palate was light bodied, smooth, creamy and slightly dry. Flavors of coffee, coca and light vanilla with a smooth dry bittersweet finish.

Bottle; dark brown/black in color with a really nice brown head.  Aroma of chocolate, roasted malt, coffee and caramel.  Very easy to drink, but also pretty flavor.  Good roasted malt in the finish.  Coffee and cocoa.  Hint of earth and chalk.  Good stuff.

Tasted 8/23/08.  22oz bomber.  Dark brown with an opaque hue.  Two fingers of beige head.  Heady aromas of chocolate and cookies.  Medium bodied with a nice roll of bitter chocolate and smooth malty body.  Slight mellowing acidity and mild effervescence.  Subtle fruity esters and yet a little thin on the body.  Touch cola, bitter chocolate and raisins.  Slight vanilla character adds to the mild malt character.  Mossy, earthy hops and a touch burnt.  Toast, dry finish.  Well crafted and tasty!

Almost black pour, tanish head.  Roasted coffee and malt nose.  Roasted/burnt malt, espresso like flavors with a little bitterness.  As it warmed just slight hints of cocoa.  Rather dry, somewhat chalky finish.  A dry stout, I think this is how it’s supposed to be.  To make it simple, I thought this was an better version of Guiness.  Excellent drinking beer.

text: Brown colored beer.  A light hint of espresso, roast and dried dark chocolate are present in the very light nose.  Flavor is lacking depth.  While it does have some nice elements (like a lingering finish,) it’s very timid in the front and mid-palate and lacks richness.  Had high hopes for this one, but it failed me.

Bottle.

Head is initially small, frothy, brown, mostly diminishing.

Aroma is moderately malty (roasted grain, coffee, cocoa), lightly hoppy (resin), with a hint of vanilla.

pours a opaque with a medium size khaki head, very good lacing.
smell of powered cocoa, weak coffee, licorice, touch of vanilla.
taste is dry, milk and bakers chocolate, some coffee, sour malt, some bitter hops, ends dry and just a little bitter.

Bottle and served in no-nik pint glass: Near opaque with a fading frothy head and okay lacing. The aroma is very roasty with a hint of grassy noble hops, fig cookies, hint of coffee and truffle. The taste is a straight forward blend of kilned malt and classic EKG bitterness. There is a soft milk chocolate sweetness and some chalky peated notes upon the finish. Simple and to the point, a solid drinking Stout... nothing wrong with that.

Pours a black color with brown highlights and a thick creamy tan head that laces nicely.  Aroma of roasted grain, malt, coffee and dark dried fruit.  Lightly sweet flavor with hints of dark roasted caramel malt, roasted grain, chocolate and coffee.  Creamy on the palate.  Long, slightly bitter, dry finish.  Not bad at all!

Very nice version of the style, which is not one of my favorites, but I  still enjoyed this beer.  Big roasty flavors...nuts, chocolate, coffee, dark roasted grain, caramel, molasses, and a nice medium dry finish.

pours a fairly opaque brown shade of black topped by a cafe au lait colored head. it’s pretty fluffy and leaves behind some trails of lace. roasted grain heavy aroma has notes of lightly charred wood, molasses, lactose, floral qualities and some weak brewed coffee. the flavor is also rich and grainy... molasses (without the sweetness), toasted nuts, burnt dark dried fruits and a tart finish akin to baker’s cocoa. coffee-like aftertaste has a nice acidity (though this is probably from the high CO2). medium to full body. creamy abundant carbonation. great for drinking a lot of...

22 oz bottle from Holiday Wine Cellar. A deep roasted malt nose that smells rich and creamy and a perfect example of how my memory would the aroma of a stout. Appears as a pitch black liquid with a small forming of foam for a head. The flavor is tad bit bland and simple but in general it still holds a decent amount of burnt dark malt and a hint of Irish cream or hazelnut in the finish.

Courtesy mgumby10.  Black, thin light tan head.  Powdered cocoa aroma, licorice, some roast, nice aroma here.  Nice dry taste, dry roast and coffee, light English hop finish.  Clean and very drinkable.
Bottle. Black body, medium head, roasty nose. Somewhat fruity, roasty, not so dry, tasty but not exactly to style.

A vigorous pour into my New Belgium globe goblet produces an almost three-finger thick, lightly browned, dark tan colored head.  The beer is quite black in color, though it does pass just a hint of light through it if held up directly to the light.  The aroma smells quite dry and full of roasted, dark malt notes; reminiscent of well, almost blackened, grain, charcoal, dry espresso, burnt soda crackers and perhaps a hint of a dark grain sweetness.  That last may just be my imagination though as this beer is clearly roast dominated and it is hard to get a sense of anything else in the nose.

Dry with a fizzy, carbonic acidity that sort of adds to the overall dryness.  Ample flavors of well deeply toasted grain move to more of burnt and even bitter finish that lingers on just a bit after the beer has left my mouth.  There is some burnt grain acidity here, though not quite as much as one might expect (the mash PH seems to have been held well enough in check).  This actually does get fairly bitter and slightly astringent in the finish from the burnt grain focus.  Despite being so dry, this does have a touch of body to it, though the fizziness of the carbonation tends to get in the way of the texture despite being fairly light (in carbonation).  A couple of vigorous swirls of my glass release most of the carbonation and greatly reduces the harsh carbonic bit and makes this beer more creamy and less astringently burnt.  As the beer warms up a bit it even picks up a slight burnt fruitiness that helps to further add a bit of balance.

I am a bit surprised to say it, but this is actually probably better on Nitro, or preferably from the hand pump; the reduced carbonation and carbonic acidity would really help to keep this beer more balanced.  And the beer does actually smooth out, become more integrated and not as overtly roasted if I vigorously swirl out the carbonation; serving this on the warm side certainly helps too.  Not exactly the best beer to be drinking out of the bottle, if you work at it you can turn this into a nicely drinking beer though.  I would love to have this served via hand pump from a cask at about 59°F / 15°C.

Purchased: Plaza Liquors, Tucson AZ
Courtesy MGumby10. Very dark brown pour that was slightly watery. Very nice chocolate malt roasty grain aroma. Chocolate malt, coffee, roasted grain taste, with a nice dryness. Very tasty.

I was actually very pleased with this. Very easy to drink with good flavors. Pitch black with thick, dark tan head. Aroma full of oatmeal, roasted barley, a small bit of chocolate, and the fresh, clean, almost piney  aroma typical of dry stouts. Flavor was same, but with more roasted barley. Very clean finish with no bitter aftertaste. Such an easy drink. Quite tasty.
Pours opaque black with off-white lasting head. Roasted malt aroma. Flavor is dry with roasted malt. Body is light. Nice and easy drinking.

22 oz. bottle from BevMo (Tucson) - Pours a clear brown color with a one and a half finger thick tan head.  Light lacing.  Aroma is toasted caramel malt and a touch of smokiness.  Flavor is toasted caramel, lightly smoked, and faint chocolate malt with a touch of coffee in there.  Palate is slightly dry.  Medium body.  Quite nice to drink.

So this beer fell short of Ryan O’ Sullivan’s Imp Stout...although still enjoyable.  Brown bordering black with a creamy latte colored head.  The nose displays roasted coffee, toasted nuts, and semi-sweet chocolate.  There is definitely a lactic quality here.  Sweeter than I would have liked but tasty.

UPDATED: AUG 14, 2009 Bottle Pitch black ale with a mid-sized, creamy, beigei head. Fantastic retention.  The nose is of espresso, nuts and chocolate with a rumor of smoke. Medium to full-bodied and astringent with dancing carbonation. Moderately sweet and equally bitter. Mocha, charcoal and toasted nuts. Crisp, charred, bone-dry finish. Bottle courtesy of mgumby10!

Pours a deep, blackish-brown.  Aroma is a touch muted, with the roasted notes being slightly subdued.  Some hints of cocoa and even lightly roasted coffee.  Flavor is solid, with a creamy flavor, redolent of cafe au lait, coming through nicely.

Pours black, with a small light brown head.  Smells of some roasty malt, light bitter chocolate, and subtle hops.  Really quite an easy drinking dry stout.  The mild vanilla and chocolate flavors blend icely with the hops and light roasty characters.  Kindo f went down smooth as silk, with some nice flavor backing up the creamy mouthfeel.  Nice drinking stout.

Pour is a nice deep almost black dark brown.  The head is small, and deep tan.  The aroma is dominated by the sweet roasty malts.  There are a lot of flavors in this beer.  The hops are fairly quite, the flavor is very chocolate/coffee with nice nutty overtones.  The roasted malts are not too strong, and give a nice splash of sweetness.  The finish is not crisp, but does not linger too long.  The body over all I would describe as medium bodied.  A very enjoyable stout.

Bottle. Poured a large tan head that mostly diminished, fair amount of lacing, very little carbonation on the sides of the glass, opaque, and a dark brown/black hue with a slight red tint. The aroma was malt, roasty, coffee, chocolate, and hops. Ditto for the flavor along with some light bitterness. The mouthfeel was smooth and the beer is light-medium bodied. A very quaffable beer for the style, easy to drink, balanced, worthy of a try, and a beer that I would drink again. Nicely done by the people at Moylans!

22oz. Bottle:  Aroma of chocolate, coffee, roasted malts, and cream.  Poured black in color with a small, dense, brown head that diminished but lasted throughout.  Opaque.  Lightly sweet, lightly bitter flavor.  Tastes of roasted malts, coffee, and chocolate.  Medium body.  Smooth, creamy texture.  Average carbonation.  Bittersweet chocolate and malt finish is not dry.  Why is this a dry stout?

Pours dark to black w/ a tall stubborn head that just sits there like a dead muledeer. Aromas of bitter cocoa. Full nectar w/ mellow effers creating an oily texture. Nice and smoooth! A moderate roast component balanced by dark unsweetened chocolate. This is one fantastic dry stout. Flavors of coffee, leather, and a pinch of molases w/ some aspirin bittering on the long finish. Beautiful!

22 oz. bottle, no freshness date, a blurb on the upper right side of the label and the ABV for Dragoons is listed as 5% in the bottom left center, sampled in a imperial pint glass.

L: Dark chocolate brown with a fluffy tan head that slowly settled into a creamy skim. Splotchy rings of lace circles the brim of the glass, Dragoons is a traditional and appealing looking Dry Irish Stout.

S: Charcoal, charred grains and mildly roasted coffee with some light fruity esters at the edges. Further whiffs reveal hints of milk chocolate and lemon zest. There are also traces of a herbal licorice. A pretty impressive nose for an Dry Irish Stout, easy to believe that Dragoons is a multi-award winner.

F&T: This has a nice airy, creamy feel in the mouth, properly light bodied, an amazing smooth drinkability, I am having to restrain myself from gulping this down. Good roasted malt flavor, barley grains, nutty coffee, chocolate licorice and a touch of sweetly dark fruits. Towards the end a delicate lemony, spicy hoppiness emerges, helping to give Dragoons a neatly dry finish.

Another well crafted, quality beer from Moylans, Dragoons Dry Irish Stout fulfills all the style requirements and then some, recommended for anyone loves Beamish or Murphys, a must try.

650 ml bottle from Bevmo. Poured an opaque black color with a big tan head that had good retention. Aroma was moderate in strength with coffee, anise and chocolate. The flavor  showcases roasted malts, chocolate and licorice. The mouthfeel starts thin but builds to a pasty fullness. The finish is long and dry with lingering roasted malts. Overall: A very drinkable dry stout. Recommended.

A large, light brown head tops a prefectly black body. The aroma has sweetened coffee and some fresh soybeans. There is also some milk chocolate and anise hints. The taste has some lightly roasted coffee along with some light anise. I get a hint of baking chocolate in the finish. There is not much else to say, but this is fairly subtle and crazy drinkable. Very nice.
Bottle from Beerfest at Sudwerk in Davis, CA.  This ones superior to Guinness in my opinion because of the fullness of the brew.  Very smooth and creamy, almost like an oatmeal.

Sample at Alans HSC initation. This brew pours an opaque dark brown/black color with ruby around the edges. Thin beige head that recedes steadily, and stringy lacing. Mellow roasted aroma of malt and coffee. Medium, smooth body with flavors of roasted malt, coffee and chocolate. Mildly hoppy at times too. The finish is sweet and roasty with a mocha aftertaste. Good session Stout all around.

22oz bottle, no date.  Almost opaque deep brown with a one finger tan head, pretty decent retention.  Roasted malts up front, with espresso (of course), with some chocolate chip cookies.  do I get a hint of pine?  The flavor, for the most part, loses its cookie sweetness.  Roasted and scorched malts follow through to the finish, but not before semisweet chocolate and pine make a swift appearance.  Ashy roasty finish with bitterness peaking around a 3.  Soft creamy medium body with low pinpoint carbonation.  Pretty good stout--glad I picked this up while in California.
